Banana-Slides: AI-Native PPT Generator - Create Professional Presentations with Natural Language

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Banana-Slides: AI-Native PPT Generator - The Future of “Vibe PPT”

Section titled “Banana-Slides: AI-Native PPT Generator - The Future of “Vibe PPT””

🍌 Create professional presentations with just one sentence - welcome to the era of AI-native PPT generation!

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Banana-Slides is an innovative, open-source AI-native PPT generator built on the nano banana pro 🍌 model. It represents a paradigm shift in presentation creation - moving from tedious manual design to natural language-driven generation. Whether you’re a non-designer needing quick professional presentations, an educator converting content to visual formats, or a business professional creating proposals rapidly, Banana-Slides offers a revolutionary approach to slide creation.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
FeatureDescription
🎯 One-Sentence CreationGenerate complete presentations from a single idea
📝 Outline-Based GenerationStructure your content and let AI fill in the design
🗣️ Natural Language EditingModify slides by simply describing what you want
📄 Smart Content ParsingUpload PDF/DOCX/MD/TXT files for intelligent extraction
🎨 Custom Template SupportUpload any template image for consistent branding
📤 One-Click ExportExport to PPTX or PDF in 16:9 format

Why Banana-Slides?

Section titled “Why Banana-Slides?”

Traditional presentation tools require extensive design skills and time investment. Banana-Slides changes this by:

  1. Eliminating Design Barriers: No need for design expertise - describe what you want in plain language
  2. Accelerating Creation: Turn hours of work into minutes
  3. Maintaining Consistency: AI ensures design coherence throughout your presentation
  4. Enabling Iteration: Modify specific regions through natural language commands

Features Deep Dive

Section titled “Features Deep Dive”

Multi-Path Creation Methods

Section titled “Multi-Path Creation Methods”

One-Sentence Generation Simply describe your presentation topic, and Banana-Slides generates a complete slide deck:

Outline-Based Creation Provide a structured outline, and AI fills in the visual design and content organization.

Page-by-Page Description For precise control, describe each slide individually and let AI handle the design.

Smart Content Processing

Section titled “Smart Content Processing”

Upload your existing documents (PDF, DOCX, Markdown, TXT) and Banana-Slides will:

  • Auto-parse content using intelligent extraction
  • Identify key points for slide highlights
  • Extract images and charts for visual enrichment
  • Structure information for optimal presentation flow

Natural Language Editing

Section titled “Natural Language Editing”

No more hunting through complex menus. Simply describe your changes:

  • “Make the title larger and center it”
  • “Add a blue gradient background to slide 3”
  • “Replace the bullet points with icons”

Export Options

Section titled “Export Options”
  • PPTX Format: Full compatibility with PowerPoint for further editing
  • PDF Format: Ready for immediate sharing or printing
  • 16:9 Aspect Ratio: Optimized for modern displays and projectors

Target Users

Section titled “Target Users”
User TypeUse Case
📊 Non-DesignersQuick professional presentations without design skills
🎨 Design ProfessionalsLayout inspiration and rapid prototyping
🎓 EducatorsConverting teaching materials to engaging visuals
📚 StudentsEfficient assignment and project presentations
💼 Business ProfessionalsRapid proposal and pitch deck creation

Technical Architecture

Section titled “Technical Architecture”

Frontend Stack

Section titled “Frontend Stack”
  • React 18 with TypeScript for robust UI development
  • Vite 5 for lightning-fast builds
  • Zustand for efficient state management
  • Tailwind CSS for responsive styling
  • @dnd-kit for drag-and-drop functionality
  • Lucide React for beautiful icons

Backend Stack

Section titled “Backend Stack”
  • Python 3.10+ with Flask 3.0
  • SQLite with Flask-SQLAlchemy for data persistence
  • Google Gemini API for AI-powered generation
  • python-pptx for PPTX export
  • Pillow for image processing

Installation & Setup

Section titled “Installation & Setup”

Option 1: Docker Compose (Recommended)

Section titled “Option 1: Docker Compose (Recommended)”

The easiest way to get started:

Option 2: From Source

Section titled “Option 2: From Source”

Prerequisites:

  • Python 3.10+
  • Node.js 16+
  • uv package manager
  • Google Gemini API key

Backend Setup:

Frontend Setup:

Configuration

Section titled “Configuration”

Create a .env file with your API credentials:

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Start with Clear Ideas

Section titled “1. Start with Clear Ideas”

The clearer your initial description, the better the AI output. Be specific about:

  • Target audience
  • Key messages
  • Desired tone (professional, casual, creative)

2. Iterate with Natural Language

Section titled “2. Iterate with Natural Language”

Don’t settle for the first output. Use natural language commands to refine:

  • “Make this more professional”
  • “Simplify the visuals”
  • “Add more data visualization”

3. Leverage Template Upload

Section titled “3. Leverage Template Upload”

For brand consistency, upload your company’s template as a reference image. Banana-Slides will maintain your brand’s visual identity.

4. Use Smart Content Parsing

Section titled “4. Use Smart Content Parsing”

Have existing content? Upload it! Banana-Slides excels at transforming written documents into engaging presentations.

Development Roadmap

Section titled “Development Roadmap”
StatusFeature
✅ CompletedMulti-path creation, file parsing, element editing, PPTX export
🚧 In ProgressElement segmentation, web search integration, Agent mode
📋 PlannedPerformance optimization, online playback, animations, multi-language support

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”
FeatureBanana-SlidesTraditional ToolsOther AI Tools
Natural Language Creation✅ Full support❌ None⚠️ Limited
Custom Template Upload✅ Any image⚠️ Specific formats❌ Rarely
Document Parsing✅ Multiple formats❌ Manual input⚠️ Some formats
Open Source✅ Yes❌ No❌ Mostly no
Self-Hosted✅ Yes❌ No❌ Rarely

Community & Support

Section titled “Community & Support”
  • GitHub Repository: Anionex/banana-slides
  • Stars: 6.1k+ ⭐
  • Forks: 690+
  • Active Development: Yes (239+ commits)

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What AI model does Banana-Slides use?

Section titled “Q: What AI model does Banana-Slides use?”

A: Banana-Slides is built on the nano banana pro 🍌 model, integrated with Google Gemini API for content generation.

Q: Can I use my own branding?

Section titled “Q: Can I use my own branding?”

A: Yes! Upload any template image, and Banana-Slides will maintain your brand’s visual consistency.

Q: Is my data safe?

Section titled “Q: Is my data safe?”

A: Self-hosting option ensures your data stays on your infrastructure. No data is sent to external services except the AI API calls.

Q: What formats can I upload for content parsing?

Section titled “Q: What formats can I upload for content parsing?”

A: PDF, DOCX, Markdown (.md), and plain text (.txt) files are supported.

Q: Can I edit the generated presentations in PowerPoint?

Section titled “Q: Can I edit the generated presentations in PowerPoint?”

A: Absolutely! Export to PPTX format and edit freely in any compatible application.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Banana-Slides represents the future of presentation creation - where your ideas flow naturally into professional slides without the friction of traditional design tools. Its open-source nature, powerful AI capabilities, and flexible deployment options make it an excellent choice for individuals and organizations looking to streamline their presentation workflows.

Ready to revolutionize your presentation workflow? 🍌

References

Section titled “References”
  • Banana-Slides GitHub Repository
  • nano banana pro Model
  • Google Gemini API Documentation
Tags:
  • AI
  • PPT
  • Presentation
  • Banana-Slides
  • Vibe PPT
  • Natural Language
  • Open Source

Gemini CLI Extensions: Supercharge Your AI Command Line

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Gemini CLI Extensions: Supercharge Your AI Command Line

Section titled “Gemini CLI Extensions: Supercharge Your AI Command Line”

OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents

Section titled “OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents”

AI coding agents have revolutionized software development, but each agent operates in its own ecosystem with unique capabilities. OpenSkills bridges this gap by bringing Anthropic’s powerful skills system to all AI coding agents.

What is OpenSkills?

Section titled “What is OpenSkills?”

OpenSkills is a universal skills loader that implements Anthropic’s Agent Skills specification for any AI coding agent. It brings Claude Code’s skills system to Cursor, Windsurf, Aider, and other agents with 100% compatibility.

Why OpenSkills Matters

Section titled “Why OpenSkills Matters”

The Problem

Section titled “The Problem”

Each AI coding agent has its own way of handling specialized capabilities:

  • Claude Code has a built-in skills system with marketplace
  • Cursor uses custom rules and instructions
  • Windsurf has its own knowledge management
  • Aider relies on conventions and prompts

This fragmentation means skills and workflows don’t transfer between agents.

The Solution

Section titled “The Solution”

OpenSkills provides a unified skills format that works across all agents:

  • Same prompt format - <available_skills> XML structure
  • Same marketplace - Access Anthropic’s official skills
  • Same folder structure - Uses .claude/skills/ by default
  • Same SKILL.md format - YAML frontmatter + markdown instructions
  • Progressive disclosure - Load skills on demand, not upfront

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Universal Compatibility

Section titled “1. Universal Compatibility”

OpenSkills works with any AI coding agent by using CLI commands instead of proprietary tool calls:

AspectClaude CodeOpenSkills
InvocationSkill("pdf")openskills read pdf
Prompt Format<available_skills> XMLIdentical
Folder Structure.claude/skills/Identical
SKILL.md FormatYAML + markdownIdentical

2. Multiple Installation Sources

Section titled “2. Multiple Installation Sources”

Install skills from various sources:

3. Progressive Disclosure

Section titled “3. Progressive Disclosure”

Skills load only when needed, keeping your agent’s context clean and focused. When the agent needs a skill:

  1. Agent scans <available_skills> in AGENTS.md
  2. Agent executes openskills read <skill-name>
  3. Full skill instructions load into context
  4. Agent follows instructions to complete task

4. Bundled Resources Support

Section titled “4. Bundled Resources Support”

Skills can include supporting resources:

Quick Start Guide

Section titled “Quick Start Guide”

Step 1: Install OpenSkills

Section titled “Step 1: Install OpenSkills”

Requires Node.js 20.6+ and Git.

Step 2: Install Skills

Section titled “Step 2: Install Skills”

Available skills from Anthropic’s marketplace:

  • pdf - PDF manipulation (extract, merge, split, forms)
  • xlsx - Spreadsheet creation and analysis
  • docx - Document creation with tracked changes
  • pptx - Presentation creation and editing
  • canvas-design - Create posters and visual designs
  • mcp-builder - Build Model Context Protocol servers
  • skill-creator - Guide for authoring skills

Step 3: Sync to AGENTS.md

Section titled “Step 3: Sync to AGENTS.md”

This updates your AGENTS.md file with the <available_skills> section:

Advanced Usage

Section titled “Advanced Usage”

Global vs Project Installation

Section titled “Global vs Project Installation”

Universal Mode for Multi-Agent Setups

Section titled “Universal Mode for Multi-Agent Setups”

If you use Claude Code alongside other agents:

This installs to .agent/skills/ to avoid conflicts with Claude Code’s native marketplace.

Priority order:

  1. ./.agent/skills/ (project universal)
  2. ~/.agent/skills/ (global universal)
  3. ./.claude/skills/ (project)
  4. ~/.claude/skills/ (global)

Local Development with Symlinks

Section titled “Local Development with Symlinks”

For active skill development:

Creating Custom Skills

Section titled “Creating Custom Skills”

Minimal Structure

Section titled “Minimal Structure”

Full Structure with Resources

Section titled “Full Structure with Resources”

Publishing

Section titled “Publishing”
  1. Create a GitHub repository with your skill
  2. Users install with: openskills install username/repo-name

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

1. Standardize Skills Across Teams

Section titled “1. Standardize Skills Across Teams”

Use OpenSkills to share skills across your organization regardless of which AI agent team members prefer:

2. Extend Claude Code’s Marketplace

Section titled “2. Extend Claude Code’s Marketplace”

Install skills from any GitHub repository, not just Anthropic’s marketplace:

3. Private Enterprise Skills

Section titled “3. Private Enterprise Skills”

Keep proprietary skills in private repositories:

4. Multi-Agent Workflows

Section titled “4. Multi-Agent Workflows”

Use the same skills whether you’re in Claude Code, Cursor, or Windsurf:

Why CLI Instead of MCP?

Section titled “Why CLI Instead of MCP?”

OpenSkills uses CLI commands rather than MCP (Model Context Protocol) because:

  1. Skills are static instructions - Not dynamic tools requiring server connections
  2. No server needed - Skills are just markdown files
  3. Universal compatibility - CLI works with any agent
  4. Follows Anthropic’s design - Skills were designed as SKILL.md files
  5. Simpler for users - No server management required

MCP and skills solve different problems. OpenSkills implements the skills spec as designed.

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Keep Skills Focused

Section titled “1. Keep Skills Focused”

Each skill should handle one specific domain. Don’t create “do everything” skills.

2. Write Clear Descriptions

Section titled “2. Write Clear Descriptions”

The description helps agents decide when to load the skill:

3. Use Progressive Disclosure

Section titled “3. Use Progressive Disclosure”

Put detailed instructions in SKILL.md, not the description. This keeps the <available_skills> section compact.

4. Include Examples

Section titled “4. Include Examples”

Help agents understand how to use your skill with concrete examples in the instructions.

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”
FeatureOpenSkillsCustom PromptsMCP
UniversalYesPer-agentRequires support
Progressive LoadingYesNoYes
Marketplace AccessYesNoDifferent
Setup ComplexityLowVariesHigher
Bundled ResourcesYesLimitedYes

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

OpenSkills democratizes AI agent skills by making Anthropic’s well-designed skills system available to all agents. Whether you’re using Claude Code, Cursor, Windsurf, or Aider, you can now benefit from:

  • Standardized skills format across agents
  • Access to Anthropic’s marketplace via GitHub
  • Progressive disclosure for clean contexts
  • Easy skill sharing within teams and communities

Get started today:

References

Section titled “References”
  • OpenSkills GitHub Repository
  • OpenSkills npm Package
  • Anthropic’s Agent Skills Blog Post
  • Anthropic Skills Marketplace (GitHub)
  • Follow @nummanali on X

  • AI

  • Agent Skills
  • Progressive Disclosure

SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills

Section titled “SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills”

AI coding assistants have become indispensable tools for developers, but their capabilities are often limited to what comes built-in. SkillsMP changes this by providing an open marketplace where developers can discover, install, and share skills across multiple AI platforms.

What is SkillsMP?

Section titled “What is SkillsMP?”

SkillsMP is an open-source marketplace hosting over 31,000 agent skills that work seamlessly with the most popular AI coding assistants:

  • Claude Code - Anthropic’s official CLI tool
  • Codex CLI - OpenAI’s command-line interface
  • ChatGPT - The world’s most popular AI assistant

All skills use the unified SKILL.md format, ensuring compatibility across platforms and making it easy to share capabilities between different AI tools.

The SKILL.md Standard

Section titled “The SKILL.md Standard”

The SKILL.md format is the foundation of the agent skills ecosystem. It defines modular capabilities through:

  • Instructions - Clear guidance for the AI on what the skill does and how to use it
  • Scripts (optional) - Supporting code that extends functionality
  • Templates (optional) - Pre-built structures for common outputs

Key Characteristics

Section titled “Key Characteristics”

Skills are model-invoked, not user-invoked. This means the AI assistant decides when to activate a skill based on the context of your request, rather than requiring explicit commands.

Installation Paths

Section titled “Installation Paths”

Different AI tools have their own skill directories:

ToolPersonal SkillsProject Skills
Claude Code~/.claude/skills/.claude/skills/
Codex CLI~/.codex/skills/.codex/skills/
ChatGPTVia plugin systemVia plugin system

Skill Categories

Section titled “Skill Categories”

SkillsMP organizes its vast library into 13 categories:

  1. Tools - General productivity enhancers
  2. Development - Code generation and refactoring
  3. Data & AI - Data analysis and ML utilities
  4. Business - Business process automation
  5. DevOps - Infrastructure and deployment
  6. Testing & Security - QA and security scanning
  7. Documentation - Docs generation and maintenance
  8. Content & Media - Content creation tools
  9. Lifestyle - Personal productivity
  10. Research - Information gathering
  11. Databases - Database operations
  12. Blockchain - Web3 and crypto tools

Quality Standards

Section titled “Quality Standards”

SkillsMP maintains quality through:

  • Minimum 2-star filter - Only GitHub repos with community validation
  • Open-source requirement - All skills are publicly auditable
  • User review recommended - Always review code before installation

Using SkillsMP

Section titled “Using SkillsMP”

Browsing Skills

Section titled “Browsing Skills”

Visit skillsmp.com to browse the marketplace. You can:

  • Search by keyword
  • Filter by category
  • Sort by popularity or recency
  • View skill documentation

Installing Skills

Section titled “Installing Skills”

For Claude Code, installation is straightforward:

Many skills also support one-command installation via their marketplace.json configuration.

Multiple Skill Execution

Section titled “Multiple Skill Execution”

Claude Code supports running multiple skills simultaneously. The AI intelligently selects which skills to activate based on context, enabling complex workflows that combine several capabilities.

Creating Custom Skills

Section titled “Creating Custom Skills”

Want to contribute to the marketplace? Creating a skill requires just a SKILL.md file:

Publishing to Marketplace

Section titled “Publishing to Marketplace”
  1. Create a GitHub repository with your skill
  2. Add a marketplace.json for easy installation
  3. Submit to SkillsMP for indexing

Independence and Official Resources

Section titled “Independence and Official Resources”

Important: SkillsMP is an independent community project. It is not affiliated with Anthropic or OpenAI.

For official skill resources:

  • Anthropic’s Official Skills: github.com/anthropics/skills
  • OpenAI’s Documentation: platform.openai.com

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

For Users

Section titled “For Users”
  1. Review before installing - Always check the source code
  2. Start with popular skills - Higher stars indicate community trust
  3. Keep skills updated - Check for updates regularly
  4. Report issues - Help improve the ecosystem

For Skill Creators

Section titled “For Skill Creators”
  1. Write clear descriptions - Help users understand when to use your skill
  2. Include examples - Show concrete use cases
  3. Document thoroughly - Explain all features and limitations
  4. Test across platforms - Ensure compatibility

The Future of AI Agent Skills

Section titled “The Future of AI Agent Skills”

The standardization around SKILL.md represents a significant shift in how we extend AI capabilities. As more developers create and share skills:

  • Specialization increases - Skills become more focused and powerful
  • Quality improves - Community curation drives excellence
  • Adoption grows - Easy installation removes barriers
  • Innovation accelerates - Building on others’ work speeds development

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

SkillsMP democratizes access to AI agent capabilities by providing:

  • 31,000+ ready-to-use skills across 13 categories
  • Cross-platform compatibility via the SKILL.md standard
  • Open-source transparency with community quality control
  • Easy installation for all major AI coding assistants

Whether you’re looking to enhance your AI coding workflow or contribute your own skills to the community, SkillsMP provides the platform to make it happen.

References

Section titled “References”
  • SkillsMP Marketplace
  • Anthropic Official Skills Repository
  • Anthropic’s Agent Skills Blog Post
  • OpenAI Platform Documentation

  • AI
  • SkillsMP
  • Claude Code
  • Codex CLI
  • ChatGPT
  • Agent Skills
  • SKILL.md
  • AI Marketplace

Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems

Section titled “Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI development, context engineering has emerged as one of the most critical disciplines for building effective agent systems. Unlike prompt engineering, which focuses on crafting effective instructions, context engineering addresses the holistic curation of all information entering a model’s limited attention window.

Agent Skills for Context Engineering by Murat Can Koylan is a comprehensive, open-source collection designed to teach the art and science of curating context to maximize agent effectiveness across any platform.

What is Context Engineering?

Section titled “What is Context Engineering?”

Context engineering is the discipline of managing the language model’s context window. The fundamental challenge is that context windows are constrained not by raw token capacity but by attention mechanics.

The Core Problem

Section titled “The Core Problem”

As context length increases, models exhibit predictable degradation patterns:

  • Lost-in-the-Middle Phenomenon - Information in the middle of long contexts gets less attention
  • U-Shaped Attention Curves - Models focus more on beginning and end of context
  • Attention Scarcity - Limited “attention budget” must be allocated wisely

The Solution

Section titled “The Solution”

Effective context engineering means finding the smallest possible set of high-signal tokens that maximize the likelihood of desired outcomes. This requires understanding what context is, how it degrades, and how to optimize it.

Skills Overview

Section titled “Skills Overview”

The collection is organized into three tiers of increasing complexity.

Foundational Skills

Section titled “Foundational Skills”

These skills establish the foundational understanding required for all subsequent context engineering work.

SkillDescription
context-fundamentalsUnderstand what context is, why it matters, and the anatomy of context in agent systems
context-degradationRecognize patterns of context failure: lost-in-middle, poisoning, distraction, and clash
context-compressionDesign and evaluate compression strategies for long-running sessions

Architectural Skills

Section titled “Architectural Skills”

These skills cover the patterns and structures for building effective agent systems.

SkillDescription
multi-agent-patternsMaster orchestrator, peer-to-peer, and hierarchical multi-agent architectures
memory-systemsDesign short-term, long-term, and graph-based memory architectures
tool-designBuild tools that agents can use effectively

Operational Skills

Section titled “Operational Skills”

These skills address the ongoing operation and optimization of agent systems.

SkillDescription
context-optimizationApply compaction, masking, and caching strategies
evaluationBuild evaluation frameworks for agent systems

Key Concepts Deep Dive

Section titled “Key Concepts Deep Dive”

1. Context Fundamentals

Section titled “1. Context Fundamentals”

Understanding the anatomy of context in agent systems is essential:

Components of Context:

  • System prompts
  • Tool definitions
  • Retrieved documents
  • Message history
  • Tool outputs

Each component competes for limited attention. Effective agents prioritize high-signal information and compress or eliminate low-signal content.

2. Context Degradation Patterns

Section titled “2. Context Degradation Patterns”

Recognizing failure patterns helps prevent them:

Lost-in-Middle: Critical information placed in the middle of long contexts receives less model attention.

Context Poisoning: Bad or conflicting information corrupts the model’s understanding.

Context Distraction: Irrelevant information diverts attention from important content.

Context Clash: Contradictory instructions or data create confusion.

3. Multi-Agent Patterns

Section titled “3. Multi-Agent Patterns”

Three primary architectures for multi-agent systems:

Orchestrator Pattern: A central agent coordinates specialized sub-agents, managing task delegation and result aggregation.

Peer-to-Peer Pattern: Agents communicate directly without central coordination, suitable for collaborative tasks.

Hierarchical Pattern: Layered agent structures where higher-level agents manage groups of lower-level agents.

4. Memory Systems

Section titled “4. Memory Systems”

Effective agents require multiple memory types:

Short-term Memory:

  • Recent conversation context
  • Current task state
  • Immediate working memory

Long-term Memory:

  • Persistent knowledge stores
  • User preferences
  • Historical patterns

Graph-based Memory:

  • Relationship maps between concepts
  • Entity connections
  • Semantic networks

Installation and Usage

Section titled “Installation and Usage”

For Claude Code

Section titled “For Claude Code”

Install skills by referencing the repository or copying skill folders into your configured skills directory:

When working on context engineering tasks, activate relevant skills to load their instructions.

For Cursor

Section titled “For Cursor”

Copy skill content into .cursorrules or create project-specific rules files:

The skills provide the context and guidelines that Cursor’s agent needs for effective context engineering.

For Custom Implementations

Section titled “For Custom Implementations”

Extract the principles and patterns from any skill and implement them in your agent framework. The skills are deliberately platform-agnostic, making them applicable to any LLM-based system.

Recommended Use Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Use Scenarios”

1. Building Production Agent Systems

Section titled “1. Building Production Agent Systems”

When developing agents for real-world deployment:

  • Start with fundamentals - Understand context anatomy before optimization
  • Design memory early - Memory architecture affects all downstream decisions
  • Plan for degradation - Build in monitoring and recovery mechanisms
  • Test at scale - Evaluation frameworks catch issues before production

2. Optimizing Existing Agents

Section titled “2. Optimizing Existing Agents”

For teams with existing agent systems:

  • Diagnose context issues - Use degradation patterns to identify problems
  • Apply compression strategies - Reduce token usage without losing signal
  • Implement caching - Avoid redundant context loading
  • Add instrumentation - Build visibility into context usage

3. Multi-Agent Architecture Design

Section titled “3. Multi-Agent Architecture Design”

When building systems with multiple coordinating agents:

  • Choose the right pattern - Orchestrator vs peer-to-peer vs hierarchical
  • Design communication protocols - How agents share context
  • Manage shared memory - Coordination without conflicts
  • Handle failures gracefully - Recovery when agents fail

4. Educational and Training Purposes

Section titled “4. Educational and Training Purposes”

For learning about agent development:

  • Progressive disclosure - Skills build on each other logically
  • Practical examples - Python pseudocode demonstrates concepts
  • Platform-agnostic - Learn principles, not vendor lock-in
  • Open source - Study, modify, and contribute

Daily Workflow Examples

Section titled “Daily Workflow Examples”

Morning Context Review

Section titled “Morning Context Review”

New Agent Development

Section titled “New Agent Development”

Debugging Agent Issues

Section titled “Debugging Agent Issues”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Design Philosophy

Section titled “Design Philosophy”

The collection follows three key principles:

1. Progressive Disclosure

Each skill is structured for efficient context use. At startup, agents load only skill names and descriptions. Full content loads only when a skill is activated for relevant tasks.

2. Platform Agnosticism

These skills focus on transferable principles rather than vendor-specific implementations. The patterns work across Claude Code, Cursor, and any agent platform that supports skills or allows custom instructions.

3. Conceptual Foundation with Practical Examples

Scripts and examples demonstrate concepts using Python pseudocode that works across environments without requiring specific dependency installations.

Skill Structure

Section titled “Skill Structure”

Each skill follows the Agent Skills specification:

Contributing Guidelines

Section titled “Contributing Guidelines”

When contributing new skills:

  1. Follow the skill template structure
  2. Provide clear, actionable instructions
  3. Include working examples where appropriate
  4. Document trade-offs and potential issues
  5. Keep SKILL.md under 500 lines for optimal performance

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”
FeatureAgent SkillsCustom RulesFramework Docs
Platform SupportAnyPlatform-specificFramework-specific
FocusContext engineeringGeneralFramework usage
StructureStandardizedVariableVariable
Progressive LoadingYesNoNo
Open SourceMITVariesVaries
ExamplesPython pseudocodeVariesFramework-specific

Why Agent Skills?

Section titled “Why Agent Skills?”

vs. Custom Rules:

  • Standardized structure enables sharing and reuse
  • Progressive disclosure reduces initial context cost
  • Community contributions expand coverage

vs. Framework Documentation:

  • Focuses on principles, not implementation details
  • Transferable across platforms
  • Practical orientation for production systems

Troubleshooting and FAQ

Section titled “Troubleshooting and FAQ”

Common Questions

Section titled “Common Questions”

Q: Do these skills work with any LLM? A: Yes, the principles are LLM-agnostic. Examples use Python pseudocode that can be adapted to any environment.

Q: How do I know which skill to use? A: Start with fundamentals, then move to architectural skills for design decisions, and operational skills for optimization.

Q: Can I contribute new skills? A: Absolutely! Follow the template structure and submit pull requests. Community contributions are welcome.

Q: Are there costs associated with using these skills? A: No, the repository is MIT licensed. However, the LLMs you use with these skills may have associated costs.

Q: How do skills handle context limits? A: Progressive disclosure means only relevant content loads. Each skill is designed to stay under 500 lines.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Skills not loading:

  • Ensure skill folder structure is correct
  • Check that SKILL.md exists in skill directory
  • Verify file permissions

Poor agent performance:

  • Review context-degradation skill for diagnostic patterns
  • Check if context window is being exceeded
  • Evaluate information signal-to-noise ratio

Multi-agent coordination issues:

  • Review multi-agent-patterns skill
  • Check message passing protocols
  • Verify shared memory access patterns

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • GitHub Repository: muratcankoylan/Agent-Skills-for-Context-Engineering
  • Skill Template: Template folder in repository
  • Examples: X-to-Book System example
  • Agent Skills Specification: Follow repository for updates

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Context engineering is becoming as fundamental to AI development as software engineering principles are to traditional development. Agent Skills for Context Engineering provides a structured, open, and platform-agnostic foundation for mastering this critical discipline.

Whether you’re building your first agent or optimizing production multi-agent systems, these skills offer the conceptual foundation and practical guidance needed for success. The progressive disclosure design means you can start small and expand as needed, while the platform-agnostic approach ensures your learning transfers across tools and frameworks.

The AI agent ecosystem is maturing rapidly, and context engineering will be a key differentiator between agents that work and agents that work well. Start with the fundamentals, understand degradation patterns, and build systems that manage context effectively.

Explore the full collection at Agent Skills for Context Engineering and join the community building better agent systems.

Tags:
  • AI
  • Agent Skills
  • Context Engineering
  • Multi-Agent
  • Claude Code
  • Cursor
  • LLM
  • Production Systems

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Dec 23, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Section titled “Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code”

In November 2025, Google introduced Code Wiki, a revolutionary platform that addresses one of software development’s most persistent challenges: keeping documentation synchronized with code. Powered by Gemini AI, Code Wiki automatically generates and maintains comprehensive, always-up-to-date documentation for any code repository.

What is Google Code Wiki?

Section titled “What is Google Code Wiki?”

Code Wiki is a new platform designed for the agentic era of software development. It maintains a continuously updated, structured wiki for code repositories, automatically regenerating documentation after every code change.

“A new perspective on development for the agentic era. Gemini-generated documentation, always up-to-date.”

The Documentation Problem

Section titled “The Documentation Problem”

Reading and understanding existing code is one of the biggest, most expensive bottlenecks in software development. Traditional documentation:

  • Gets outdated quickly - Code changes faster than docs can be updated
  • Lacks context - Static docs don’t explain relationships between components
  • Requires manual effort - Engineers spend time writing docs instead of coding
  • Becomes inconsistent - Different authors, different styles, incomplete coverage

Code Wiki solves these problems through automated, AI-powered documentation generation.

Core Features & Highlights

Section titled “Core Features & Highlights”

1. Automatic Documentation Generation

Section titled “1. Automatic Documentation Generation”

Code Wiki scans entire repositories and generates structured documentation automatically:

  • Full codebase analysis - Understands all files, functions, and relationships
  • Regeneration on every commit - Docs update automatically with each change
  • Architecture diagrams - Visual representations generated and kept current
  • Class and sequence diagrams - Technical visualizations for complex systems

2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface

Section titled “2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface”

Each Code Wiki page includes an intelligent chat agent:

  • Context-aware Q&A - Ask specific questions about YOUR codebase
  • Full wiki knowledge - Chat uses the complete, current documentation as context
  • Direct code links - Answers include hyperlinks to relevant source files
  • Natural language queries - Ask questions in plain English

Example interactions:

  • “How does the authentication module work?”
  • “What functions call the database connection pool?”
  • “Explain the data flow in the payment processing system”

3. Hyperlinked Navigation

Section titled “3. Hyperlinked Navigation”

Every documentation element connects directly to source code:

  • Symbol linking - Click any function, class, or variable to see its definition
  • Cross-references - Navigate between related concepts seamlessly
  • File locations - Know exactly where code lives
  • Definition chains - Trace from high-level concepts to implementation details

4. Powered by NotebookLM

Section titled “4. Powered by NotebookLM”

Code Wiki integrates with Google’s NotebookLM for enhanced documentation:

  • Video explanations - Auto-generated video walkthroughs of codebases
  • Interactive presentations - Architecture overviews with multimedia
  • Audio summaries - Listen to code explanations (coming soon)

Prerequisites & Getting Started

Section titled “Prerequisites & Getting Started”

Accessing Code Wiki

Section titled “Accessing Code Wiki”

Public Preview (Available Now):

  1. Visit codewiki.google
  2. Search for any public open-source repository
  3. Code Wiki generates documentation automatically

Supported Repositories:

  • GitHub public repositories
  • GitLab public projects
  • Bitbucket public repos

Featured Repositories

Section titled “Featured Repositories”

Code Wiki showcases documentation for popular projects:

RepositoryStarsDescription
gemini-cli81.5kOpen-source AI agent for terminal
go130.7kThe Go programming language
flutter173.7kBuild beautiful apps for mobile
kubernetes118.4kContainer orchestration platform
react240.3kWeb and native UI library
python-sdk19.8kMCP Python SDK

Gemini CLI Extension (Coming Soon)

Section titled “Gemini CLI Extension (Coming Soon)”

For private repositories, Google is developing a Gemini CLI extension:

  • Local deployment - Keep sensitive code on your infrastructure
  • Enterprise security - Meets compliance requirements
  • Legacy codebase support - Perfect for undocumented systems
  • Join the waitlist at codewiki.google

Recommended Use Cases

Section titled “Recommended Use Cases”

1. Onboarding New Team Members

Section titled “1. Onboarding New Team Members”

Code Wiki dramatically accelerates developer onboarding:

Before Code Wiki:

  • 2-4 weeks to understand codebase structure
  • Constant questions to senior developers
  • Reading outdated documentation
  • Trial-and-error exploration

With Code Wiki:

  • Understand system architecture in minutes
  • Ask specific questions, get accurate answers
  • Self-service exploration with chat assistant
  • Meaningful contributions on day one

2. Understanding Legacy Codebases

Section titled “2. Understanding Legacy Codebases”

For teams inheriting undocumented systems:

  • Automatic documentation - Generate docs for any codebase
  • Architecture discovery - See how components interact
  • Dependency mapping - Understand what connects to what
  • Knowledge preservation - Capture institutional knowledge

3. Code Reviews and Audits

Section titled “3. Code Reviews and Audits”

Streamline review processes:

  • Quick context - Reviewers understand changes faster
  • Impact analysis - See what code connects to modified areas
  • Consistent understanding - Everyone reads the same docs
  • Security audits - Faster codebase comprehension

4. Open Source Exploration

Section titled “4. Open Source Exploration”

Evaluate and learn from open source projects:

  • Rapid evaluation - Understand projects before adopting
  • Learning tool - See how major projects are structured
  • Contribution prep - Understand codebase before contributing
  • Pattern discovery - Learn architectural approaches

Daily Workflow Examples

Section titled “Daily Workflow Examples”

Developer Morning Routine

Section titled “Developer Morning Routine”

New Feature Development

Section titled “New Feature Development”

Debugging Workflow

Section titled “Debugging Workflow”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Maximizing Code Wiki Value

Section titled “Maximizing Code Wiki Value”
  1. Use specific questions - “How does X work?” beats “Tell me about the code”
  2. Follow hyperlinks - Navigate from docs to code for verification
  3. Refresh regularly - Check for updated docs after team commits
  4. Combine with IDE - Keep Code Wiki open alongside your editor

For Team Leads

Section titled “For Team Leads”
  1. Share wiki links - Point team members to relevant sections
  2. Standardize onboarding - Include Code Wiki in new hire checklist
  3. Reference in reviews - Use wiki links in PR discussions
  4. Monitor coverage - Identify areas needing better documentation

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”
FeatureCode WikiReadMeDocusaurusGitBook
Auto-generationYes (Gemini)ManualManualManual
Real-time updatesEvery commitManualManualManual
AI chat assistantYesNoNoNo
Diagram generationAutomaticManualManualManual
Code linkingAutomaticManualManualManual
Setup requiredNoneConfigurationFull setupConfiguration
Private reposComing soonYesYesYes

Advantages Over Traditional Documentation

Section titled “Advantages Over Traditional Documentation”

vs. Manual Documentation:

  • No maintenance overhead
  • Always current
  • Consistent formatting
  • Complete coverage

vs. Code Comments:

  • Higher-level understanding
  • Cross-file relationships
  • Visual diagrams
  • Searchable and navigable

vs. README files:

  • Comprehensive depth
  • Interactive chat
  • Auto-updated
  • Architecture views

FAQ & Troubleshooting

Section titled “FAQ & Troubleshooting”

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: Is Code Wiki free? A: Public preview for open-source repos is free. Private repo pricing TBD.

Q: How quickly does documentation update? A: Documentation regenerates after each commit, typically within minutes.

Q: Can I customize the generated documentation? A: Currently documentation is fully automated. Custom templates may come later.

Q: Does Code Wiki support all programming languages? A: Gemini AI supports most popular languages. Quality may vary for niche languages.

Q: Is my code sent to Google’s servers? A: For public repos, yes. The CLI extension for private repos will enable local processing.

Q: Can I export the documentation? A: Export features are on the roadmap. Currently, documentation lives on codewiki.google.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Documentation not appearing:

  • Verify the repository is public
  • Check that the repo URL is correct
  • Wait a few minutes for initial generation

Chat not responding:

  • Refresh the page
  • Try a more specific question
  • Check your network connection

Diagrams missing:

  • Complex repos may take longer to process
  • Some architectural patterns may not visualize well
  • Check back after a few minutes

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • Official Site: codewiki.google
  • Google Developers Blog: Introducing Code Wiki
  • Gemini CLI Waitlist: Available at codewiki.google
  • NotebookLM: notebooklm.google

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Google Code Wiki represents a fundamental shift in how we approach code documentation. By leveraging Gemini AI to automatically generate and maintain comprehensive, always-current documentation, Code Wiki eliminates one of software development’s most persistent pain points.

For open-source projects, the public preview is available now. For enterprise teams with private codebases, the upcoming Gemini CLI extension promises the same benefits with local deployment and security compliance.

Whether you’re onboarding new developers, exploring unfamiliar codebases, or simply wanting to understand how your own code works, Code Wiki provides an intelligent, always-updated companion for your development journey.

Try Code Wiki today at codewiki.google and experience the future of code documentation.

Tags:
  • AI
  • Google
  • Gemini
  • Documentation
  • Code Wiki
  • Developer Tools
  • Agentic AI

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Section titled “Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI tools, Fabric stands out as a revolutionary open-source framework designed to bridge the gap between AI capabilities and human integration. Created by security researcher and AI enthusiast Daniel Miessler, Fabric addresses a fundamental problem: AI doesn’t have a capabilities problem—it has an integration problem.

What is Fabric?

Section titled “What is Fabric?”

Fabric is an open-source framework that organizes and manages AI prompts—called Patterns—in a modular, reusable system. Unlike scattered prompts across various tools and platforms, Fabric provides a centralized, command-line-first approach to collecting, organizing, and executing AI solutions.

The Philosophy Behind Fabric

Section titled “The Philosophy Behind Fabric”

“AI isn’t a thing; it’s a magnifier of a thing. And that thing is human creativity.”

Fabric’s philosophy centers on breaking complex problems into manageable components and applying AI to each piece systematically. This approach transforms AI from a mysterious black box into a practical, everyday tool.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Pattern-Based Architecture

Section titled “1. Pattern-Based Architecture”

Patterns are the core building blocks of Fabric. Each Pattern is a carefully crafted prompt designed for a specific real-world task:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from YouTube videos and podcasts
  • summarize: Create concise summaries of any content
  • analyze_claims: Evaluate claims for accuracy and validity
  • write_essay: Generate essays in your own voice
  • create_coding_feature: Generate code features with context
  • improve_writing: Enhance writing quality and clarity

With over 150+ built-in Patterns, Fabric covers diverse use cases from content creation to code analysis.

2. Multi-Model Support

Section titled “2. Multi-Model Support”

Fabric supports an impressive array of AI providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT-4, GPT-4o, o1, o3)
  • Anthropic (Claude 4, Claude 4.5 Opus)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • Local models via Ollama
  • Azure OpenAI
  • Amazon Bedrock
  • Perplexity AI
  • Venice AI (privacy-focused)
  • Together AI
  • And many more…

3. Seamless CLI Integration

Section titled “3. Seamless CLI Integration”

Fabric is built for the command line, making it perfect for developers and power users:

4. Context and Session Management

Section titled “4. Context and Session Management”

Fabric supports persistent contexts and sessions:

  • Contexts: Pre-created background information added to all queries
  • Sessions: Maintain conversation history across multiple interactions
  • Variables: Dynamic pattern customization with {{variable}} syntax

5. REST API Server

Section titled “5. REST API Server”

Fabric includes a built-in REST API server for integration with other applications:

Features include:

  • Chat completions with streaming
  • Pattern management (CRUD operations)
  • YouTube transcript extraction
  • Swagger/OpenAPI documentation

6. Web Interface

Section titled “6. Web Interface”

A GUI alternative to the CLI is available for those who prefer visual interfaces, providing access to all Fabric functionality through a web browser.

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Fabric, ensure you have:

  • Go 1.22+ (for source installation)
  • API keys for your preferred AI providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.)
  • yt-dlp (optional, for YouTube transcript extraction)
  • LaTeX distribution (optional, for PDF generation with to_pdf)

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

1. Command not found after installation:

2. API key errors:

3. YouTube transcripts not working:

4. Pattern not found:

5. Model not available:

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is Fabric free to use? A: Yes, Fabric is MIT licensed. However, you need API keys for AI providers, which may have costs.

Q: Can I use Fabric without internet? A: Yes, with local models through Ollama.

Q: How do I contribute patterns? A: Submit a pull request to the Fabric repository with your pattern in the data/patterns directory.

Q: Does Fabric store my data? A: Fabric processes data locally. Data is sent to AI providers based on your configuration.

Q: Can I use multiple models in one workflow? A: Yes, you can chain patterns with different models using shell pipes.

Recent Updates (December 2025)

Section titled “Recent Updates (December 2025)”
  • v1.4.350: Interactive API Documentation with Swagger/OpenAPI UI
  • v1.4.338: Abacus vendor support for Chat-LLM models
  • v1.4.334: Claude Opus 4.5 model support
  • v1.4.322: Interactive HTML Concept Maps with Vis.js
  • v1.4.309: Comprehensive internationalization (9 languages)

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • GitHub Repository: github.com/danielmiessler/fabric
  • Pattern Library: Fabric Patterns
  • REST API Documentation: REST API Docs
  • Intro Videos:
    • Network Chuck Introduction
    • David Bombal Tutorial
    • Daniel Miessler’s Overview
  • Daniel Miessler’s Website: danielmiessler.com

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Fabric represents a paradigm shift in how we interact with AI. By providing a structured, modular, and command-line-friendly framework, it transforms AI from an occasional tool into an integrated part of our daily workflows. Whether you’re a developer, content creator, security researcher, or knowledge worker, Fabric’s pattern-based approach offers a powerful way to augment your capabilities with AI.

The project’s active development, growing community, and extensive pattern library make it an essential tool for anyone serious about leveraging AI effectively. Start with the basic patterns, explore the community contributions, and eventually create your own—that’s the path to truly augmented human productivity.

This article was researched and written with assistance from AI tools, demonstrating the very integration that Fabric enables.

Claude Scientific Skills: 125+ Ready-to-Use AI-Powered Scientific Research Workflows

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Claude Scientific Skills: 125+ Ready-to-Use AI-Powered Scientific Research Workflows

Section titled “Claude Scientific Skills: 125+ Ready-to-Use AI-Powered Scientific Research Workflows”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI-assisted research, Claude Scientific Skills emerges as a game-changing toolkit that transforms Claude into a powerful scientific research assistant. Created by K-Dense-AI, this comprehensive collection of 125+ specialized skills enables researchers to leverage AI across diverse scientific domains without writing complex prompts from scratch.

What is Claude Scientific Skills?

Section titled “What is Claude Scientific Skills?”

Claude Scientific Skills is an open-source collection of ready-to-use scientific skills designed specifically for Claude. Each skill is a carefully crafted prompt template that guides Claude to perform specific scientific tasks with precision and domain expertise.

“Transform your Claude assistant into a specialized scientific research tool with just a few clicks.”

Key Statistics

Section titled “Key Statistics”
  • 125+ Scientific Skills covering diverse research domains
  • 26+ Scientific Databases integrated for data access
  • 54+ Python Packages recommended for scientific computing
  • 15+ Scientific Integrations with industry platforms
  • 20+ Real-World Workflows documented with examples

Core Features & Highlights

Section titled “Core Features & Highlights”

1. Comprehensive Domain Coverage

Section titled “1. Comprehensive Domain Coverage”

Claude Scientific Skills spans multiple scientific disciplines:

Bioinformatics & Genomics:

  • Sequence analysis and alignment
  • Variant calling and annotation
  • Gene expression analysis
  • Pathway enrichment studies

Cheminformatics & Drug Discovery:

  • Molecular property prediction
  • ADMET analysis
  • Chemical similarity searching
  • Compound library design

Proteomics & Structural Biology:

  • Protein structure prediction
  • Binding site analysis
  • Post-translational modification detection
  • Protein-protein interaction networks

Clinical Research:

  • Patient cohort analysis
  • Biomarker discovery
  • Clinical trial design assistance
  • Survival analysis workflows

Medical Imaging:

  • Image preprocessing pipelines
  • Feature extraction workflows
  • Radiomics analysis
  • Multi-modal image fusion

Machine Learning & AI:

  • Model selection guidance
  • Hyperparameter optimization
  • Feature engineering strategies
  • Experiment tracking workflows

Section titled “2. Integrated Scientific Databases”

Access 26+ databases directly through skills:

  • Benchling - Lab notebook and molecular biology
  • DNAnexus - Genomics data analysis
  • LatchBio - Bioinformatics workflows
  • OMERO - Microscopy data management
  • Protocols.io - Method sharing
  • Weights & Biases - ML experiment tracking

Installation Options

Section titled “Installation Options”

Option 1: Claude Code Marketplace (Recommended)

Section titled “Option 1: Claude Code Marketplace (Recommended)”

The easiest way to install:

  1. Open Claude Code
  2. Navigate to the Marketplace
  3. Search for “K-Dense-AI Scientific Skills”
  4. Click Install

Option 2: Cursor IDE

Section titled “Option 2: Cursor IDE”

For Cursor users:

  1. Open Cursor Settings
  2. Go to AI > Skills
  3. Add the K-Dense-AI repository
  4. Enable desired skills

  • Combine multiple skills for complex workflows
  • Start with exploratory skills before detailed analysis

  • Ensure data formats match skill requirements
  • Validate input data quality before analysis
  • Use recommended file formats (FASTA, PDB, CSV)

  • Cross-reference results with multiple databases
  • Verify computational predictions experimentally
  • Document assumptions and limitations

Troubleshooting & FAQ

Section titled “Troubleshooting & FAQ”

Q: Skills not appearing in Claude?

Section titled “Q: Skills not appearing in Claude?”

A: Ensure the MCP server is properly configured and restart Claude Code.

Q: Database queries returning empty results?

Section titled “Q: Database queries returning empty results?”

A: Check API keys are configured correctly and database services are accessible.

Q: Python code not executing?

Section titled “Q: Python code not executing?”

A: Verify required packages are installed in your environment.

Q: How do I create custom skills?

Section titled “Q: How do I create custom skills?”

A: Follow the skill template in the repository’s templates/ directory.

Q: Can I use skills offline?

Section titled “Q: Can I use skills offline?”

A: Yes, most skills work offline. Database queries require internet access.

Q: How often are skills updated?

Section titled “Q: How often are skills updated?”

A: The repository is actively maintained with regular updates for new databases and methods.

  • New Quantum Computing Skills - Qiskit integration for quantum chemistry
  • Enhanced ML Workflows - PyTorch Lightning support
  • Clinical Trial Tools - ClinicalTrials.gov deep integration
  • Improved Documentation - 20+ detailed workflow examples

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Scientific Skills represents a significant advancement in AI-assisted scientific research. By providing 125+ specialized skills with deep integration into scientific databases, Python ecosystems, and industry platforms, it transforms Claude from a general-purpose assistant into a powerful research partner.

Whether you’re a bioinformatician analyzing genomic data, a chemist searching for drug candidates, a clinician interpreting variants, or a data scientist building ML pipelines, Claude Scientific Skills provides the domain expertise and workflow guidance you need.

The project’s commitment to open-source development, active maintenance, and comprehensive documentation makes it an essential toolkit for any researcher looking to leverage AI in their scientific workflows. Start with a single skill, explore the documented workflows, and discover how AI can accelerate your research.

Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner

Section titled “Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner”

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

What if your AI assistant could not only understand your code but also execute commands, manage files, and work across your entire operating system? Desktop Commander MCP makes this possible, transforming Claude Desktop into a powerful, autonomous development partner that goes far beyond traditional IDE-focused AI tools.

Created by Eduard Ruzga (wonderwhy-er), Desktop Commander MCP is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that bridges Claude Desktop with your local system. With over thousands of weekly npm downloads and a growing community of enthusiastic developers, it’s rapidly becoming the go-to solution for developers who want AI-assisted development without the fragmentation of multiple tools.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

🚀 Enhanced Terminal Control

Section titled “🚀 Enhanced Terminal Control”

Desktop Commander provides intelligent terminal integration with:

  • Smart process detection - Automatically knows when programs are ready for input
  • Interactive session management - Maintain long-running sessions (SSH, databases, dev servers)
  • Background execution - Run commands with timeout support
  • Process control - List, monitor, and terminate processes

📁 Comprehensive File Operations

Section titled “📁 Comprehensive File Operations”
  • Full filesystem access with intelligent permissions
  • Native Excel support (.xlsx, .xls, .xlsm) - read, write, edit, search
  • PDF capabilities - Extract text, create from markdown, modify existing PDFs
  • Surgical code editing - Search/replace blocks for precise changes
  • Pattern-based replacements with vscode-ripgrep integration
  • URL support - Fetch content from web resources directly

💻 In-Memory Code Execution

Section titled “💻 In-Memory Code Execution”

Execute code without saving files:

🔧 Configuration Management

Section titled “🔧 Configuration Management”

Dynamic runtime configuration:

  • Blocked commands for security
  • Shell preferences (bash, zsh, PowerShell)
  • Directory access controls
  • File read/write limits

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled “Prerequisites and Installation”

System Requirements

Section titled “System Requirements”
  • Node.js (v16 or higher recommended)
  • Claude Desktop application
  • Operating System: macOS, Windows, or Linux

Installation Options

Section titled “Installation Options”

Option 1: NPX (Recommended - Auto-Updates)

Section titled “Option 1: NPX (Recommended - Auto-Updates)”

Option 2: macOS Bash Script

Section titled “Option 2: macOS Bash Script”

Option 3: Docker (Complete Isolation)

Section titled “Option 3: Docker (Complete Isolation)”

Option 4: Manual Configuration

Section titled “Option 4: Manual Configuration”

Add to your claude_desktop_config.json:

Config locations:

  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json
  • Windows: %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json
  • Linux: ~/.config/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json

Recommended Scenarios and Daily Workflow

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Daily Workflow”

1. Codebase Exploration and Documentation

Section titled “1. Codebase Exploration and Documentation”

2. Multi-Project Development

Section titled “2. Multi-Project Development”

Unlike IDE tools limited to one workspace, Claude with Desktop Commander can:

  • Work across multiple repositories simultaneously
  • Compare implementations between projects
  • Copy patterns from one project to another

3. Automated DevOps Tasks

Section titled “3. Automated DevOps Tasks”

4. Data Analysis

Section titled “4. Data Analysis”

5. Interactive Development Environments

Section titled “5. Interactive Development Environments”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Security-First Configuration

Section titled “Security-First Configuration”
  1. Use dedicated configuration chats - Make config changes in separate conversations
  2. Set specific allowedDirectories - Limit filesystem access to needed paths
  3. Review blockedCommands - Prevent dangerous command execution
  4. Consider Docker for sensitive work - Complete isolation from host system

Efficient File Editing

Section titled “Efficient File Editing”

The edit_block tool uses search/replace blocks for surgical edits:

Pro Tips:

  • Make multiple small edits instead of large rewrites
  • Keep fileWriteLineLimit small to encourage efficient behavior
  • Use fuzzy search logs for debugging match failures

Session Management

Section titled “Session Management”

For long-running operations:

  1. Use start_process with smart ready detection
  2. Interact via interact_with_process
  3. Monitor with read_process_output
  4. Clean up with force_terminate

Comparison with Similar Tools

Section titled “Comparison with Similar Tools”
FeatureDesktop CommanderCursorWindsurf
ScopeEntire OSSingle projectSingle project
File ReadingFull filesChunkedChunked
Multi-Project✅ Yes❌ No❌ No
Terminal Control✅ Interactive⚠️ Limited⚠️ Limited
Cost ModelPro subscriptionAPI tokensAPI tokens
Token EconomyEfficientCan cascadeCan cascade

Why Developers Are Switching

Section titled “Why Developers Are Switching”

From the community testimonials:

“It’s a life saver! I paid for Claude + Cursor which always felt duplicated. This solves the problem ultimately.”

“Claude first to keep my sanity in check, then if necessary, engage with other IDEs.”

“I was able to compare old and new codebase fully, accounting for updates in the code, and fix issues in hours that I’d spent days on with other tools.”

Precautions and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions and Troubleshooting”

Known Limitations

Section titled “Known Limitations”
  1. Directory restrictions can be bypassed - Security through allowedDirectories is not absolute
  2. Terminal commands unrestricted - allowedDirectories only affects file operations
  3. File write limits - Default 50 lines per write to encourage efficient AI behavior

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Claude times out:

  • Ensure MCP server is running
  • Check config JSON syntax
  • Restart Claude Desktop

Commands fail:

  • Verify shell path in configuration
  • Check command isn’t in blockedCommands
  • Ensure proper permissions

File access denied:

  • Add path to allowedDirectories
  • Verify file permissions on disk

Debug Mode

Section titled “Debug Mode”

For troubleshooting:

Connect debugger to Node.js process on port 9229.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Do I need API credits? A: No. Works with Claude Desktop Pro subscription ($20/month), not API calls.

Q: Does it auto-update? A: Yes, when installed via npx or Smithery, updates apply on Claude restart.

Q: Is my data collected? A: Limited pseudonymous telemetry only. No file contents or paths. Opt-out available.

Q: Can I use it with other Claude clients? A: Designed for Claude Desktop. Community adapters may exist for other clients.

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • GitHub Repository: wonderwhy-er/DesktopCommanderMCP
  • NPM Package: @wonderwhy-er/desktop-commander
  • Official Website: desktopcommander.app
  • Discord Community: Join Server
  • Video Tutorial: YouTube Setup Guide
  • Author’s Article: Claude with MCPs Replaced Cursor & Windsurf

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Desktop Commander MCP represents a paradigm shift in AI-assisted development. By giving Claude direct access to your terminal and filesystem, it transforms conversational AI into an active development partner. Whether you’re exploring unfamiliar codebases, automating DevOps tasks, or building new features, Desktop Commander puts all your development tools in one intelligent chat interface.

The solution-centric approach—working with your entire OS rather than a single IDE workspace—combined with the cost efficiency of subscription-based pricing, makes it an compelling alternative to fragmented, API-token-hungry alternatives.

Ready to supercharge your development workflow? Install Desktop Commander and experience the future of AI-assisted development today.

Tags:
  • MCP
  • Claude
  • AI
  • Desktop Commander
  • Automation
  • Development
  • Terminal
  • File Management

Desktop Commander MCP: Terminal Control & File System Access for Claude

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Desktop Commander MCP: Terminal Control & File System Access for Claude

Section titled “Desktop Commander MCP: Terminal Control & File System Access for Claude”

In the rapidly evolving AI development landscape, Desktop Commander MCP stands out as a game-changing tool that transforms Claude Desktop into a powerful desktop automation assistant. Unlike traditional IDE-focused tools, Desktop Commander provides a solution-centric approach that works with your entire operating system.

What is Desktop Commander MCP?

Section titled “What is Desktop Commander MCP?”

Desktop Commander MCP is an open-source MCP (Model Context Protocol) server created by wonderwhy-er that enables Claude to:

  • Execute terminal commands with output streaming
  • Search and manage file systems
  • Edit files with surgical precision using diff capabilities
  • Read and write Excel, PDF, and various data files
  • Run code in memory without file persistence

“Work with code and text, run processes and automate tasks beyond typical AI editor limitations.”

Key Features & Highlights

Section titled “Key Features & Highlights”

1. Terminal & Process Control

Section titled “1. Terminal & Process Control”

Desktop Commander provides comprehensive terminal management:

Capabilities include:

  • Command execution with configurable timeouts
  • Background process execution
  • Process listing and termination
  • Session management for SSH, databases, and development servers

2. Native Data File Support

Section titled “2. Native Data File Support”

One of Desktop Commander’s standout features is native file handling:

Excel Support (.xlsx, .xls, .xlsm):

  • Read, write, and edit spreadsheets
  • Search within Excel files
  • No external tools required

PDF Support:

  • Text extraction from PDF documents
  • PDF creation from markdown
  • Document modification capabilities

Data Analysis:

  • Instant CSV/JSON file analysis
  • Quick data exploration without setup

3. Advanced File Operations

Section titled “3. Advanced File Operations”

4. Surgical Code Editing

Section titled “4. Surgical Code Editing”

Desktop Commander offers two editing approaches:

  1. Targeted Replacements - For precise, surgical changes
  2. Full File Rewrites - For major modifications

Multi-file support with pattern-based replacements makes refactoring efficient.

5. In-Memory Code Execution

Section titled “5. In-Memory Code Execution”

Execute code without file persistence:

  • Python - Run Python scripts directly
  • Node.js - Execute JavaScript/TypeScript
  • R - Statistical computing support

6. Configuration Management

Section titled “6. Configuration Management”
  • Dynamic get/set configuration values
  • Batch settings updates
  • Changes without server restart

7. Audit Logging

Section titled “7. Audit Logging”
  • Automatic logging of all tool calls
  • 10MB log rotation limit
  • Detailed timestamps and arguments

Installation Options

Section titled “Installation Options”

Option 1: NPX (⭐ Recommended - Auto-Updates)

Section titled “Option 1: NPX (⭐ Recommended - Auto-Updates)”

Option 2: Bash Installer (macOS)

Section titled “Option 2: Bash Installer (macOS)”

Option 3: Smithery

Section titled “Option 3: Smithery”

Visit smithery.ai/server/@wonderwhy-er/desktop-commander

Option 4: Manual Configuration

Section titled “Option 4: Manual Configuration”

Add to claude_desktop_config.json:

Config file locations:

  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json
  • Windows: %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json
  • Linux: ~/.config/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json

Option 5: Local Checkout

Section titled “Option 5: Local Checkout”

Option 6: Docker 🐳 (No Node.js Required)

Section titled “Option 6: Docker 🐳 (No Node.js Required)”

Docker Configuration:

Recommended Scenarios & Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios & Best Practices”

1. Development Workflow Automation

Section titled “1. Development Workflow Automation”

Real user feedback:

“I had 76 errors in 23 files in my Svelte 5 project. Used desktop-commander, sequentialthinking, and tree-sitter to fix them all. Never resolved type errors this quickly with AI before!“

2. Data Analysis Pipeline

Section titled “2. Data Analysis Pipeline”

3. System Administration

Section titled “3. System Administration”

4. Codebase Exploration

Section titled “4. Codebase Exploration”

5. Sandboxed Development (Docker)

Section titled “5. Sandboxed Development (Docker)”

For enhanced security, use Docker isolation:

  • Controlled environment with persistent development state
  • Selective folder access without full filesystem exposure
  • Installed tools and configurations persist across sessions

Daily Workflow Examples

Section titled “Daily Workflow Examples”

Morning Code Review

Section titled “Morning Code Review”

Documentation Update

Section titled “Documentation Update”

Database Management

Section titled “Database Management”

File Organization

Section titled “File Organization”

Precautions & Security

Section titled “Precautions & Security”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Use Docker for Isolation - Provides controlled environment
  2. Configure Command Blacklists - Restrict dangerous commands
  3. Set Directory Permissions - Limit access to specific folders
  4. Review Audit Logs - Monitor all executed commands
  5. Backup Before Operations - Especially for destructive tasks

Security Controls

Section titled “Security Controls”

Desktop Commander provides:

  • Command blacklist configuration
  • Directory access permissions
  • Audit logging for all operations
  • Telemetry opt-out options

Comparison with Similar Tools

Section titled “Comparison with Similar Tools”
FeatureDesktop CommanderMCP Filesystem ServerIDE Extensions
Terminal Control✅ Full❌ NoneLimited
File Search✅ RipgrepBasicVaries
Excel Support✅ Native❌ NonePlugin needed
PDF Support✅ Native❌ NonePlugin needed
Diff Editing✅ SurgicalBasic✅ Yes
Code Execution✅ In-memory❌ NoneVaries
Process Management✅ Full❌ NoneLimited
Docker Support✅ Yes❌ NoN/A
Auto-Updates✅ Options 1-4, 6ManualVia store

Recent Updates (2025)

Section titled “Recent Updates (2025)”
  • v0.1.40 (May 20) - Audit logging, improved line-based operations, enhanced edit_block
  • Fuzzy Search Logging (May 5) - Comprehensive logging for search operations
  • Telemetry Opt-out (April 29) - Configuration-based telemetry control
  • Better Code Search (March 25) - Enhanced context-aware results
  • WSL Support - Windows Subsystem for Linux exploration

Troubleshooting & FAQ

Section titled “Troubleshooting & FAQ”

Q: Commands are timing out

Section titled “Q: Commands are timing out”

A: Increase timeout in configuration or use background execution for long-running tasks.

Q: Permission denied errors

Section titled “Q: Permission denied errors”

A: Check directory access permissions in Desktop Commander configuration.

Q: Docker container not persisting data

Section titled “Q: Docker container not persisting data”

A: Use volume mounts (-v flag) for data persistence.

Q: Can’t find files with search

Section titled “Q: Can’t find files with search”

A: Ensure the search path is within allowed directories and try adjusting the search pattern.

Q: Updates not applying

Section titled “Q: Updates not applying”

A: For Options 1-4 and 6, restart Claude. For Option 5, run git pull && npm run setup.

Uninstallation

Section titled “Uninstallation”

Automatic (Recommended)

Section titled “Automatic (Recommended)”

Manual

Section titled “Manual”

Edit claude_desktop_config.json and remove the “desktop-commander” entry from mcpServers.

Community & Support

Section titled “Community & Support”
  • Website: desktopcommander.app
  • GitHub: wonderwhy-er/DesktopCommanderMCP
  • Discord: Join the Community
  • License: MIT (Free and Open Source)

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Desktop Commander MCP represents a paradigm shift in how we interact with AI assistants for desktop automation. By providing Claude with comprehensive terminal control, file system access, and native data file support, it transforms Claude from a conversational AI into a powerful automation partner.

Whether you’re a developer looking to streamline your workflow, a data analyst needing quick insights, or a system administrator automating routine tasks, Desktop Commander MCP offers the tools you need. Its active development, growing community, and commitment to open-source principles make it an essential addition to any Claude Desktop setup.

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • Desktop Commander Official Website
  • GitHub Repository
  • Smithery Server Page
  • Discord Community
  • MCP Protocol Documentation
  • Claude Desktop Setup Guide
Tags:
  • AI
  • MCP
  • Claude
  • Terminal
  • Automation
  • Desktop Commander
  • File System
  • Developer Tools

Daily Journal - 2025-12-17 Accenture and Anthropic partnership

Dec 17, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Accenture and Anthropic launch multi-year partnership to move enterprises from AI pilots to production

Section titled “Accenture and Anthropic launch multi-year partnership to move enterprises from AI pilots to production”

  • [[Forward Deployed Engineer]] / [[Reinvention Deployed Engineer]]

    • Approximately 30,000 Accenture professionals that will be trained on Claude, including forward deployed engineers (also known as “reinvention deployed engineers” at Accenture) who help embed Claude within client environments to scale enterprise AI adoption. This will comprise one of the largest ecosystems of Claude practitioners in the world. These teams combine Accenture’s AI, industry, and function expertise—along with deep partnerships with leading cloud providers—with Anthropic’s Claude models and Claude Code, plus its proven playbooks for regulated industries.

  • [[Methodology]]

    • quantify real productivity gains and ROI
    • workflow redesign for AI-first development teams
    • change management and training that keeps pace as AI evolves

  • [[Customization]]

    • Anthropic and Accenture will also co-invest in a Claude Center of Excellence inside Accenture, creating a dedicated environment for the joint design of new AI offerings tailored to specific enterprise needs, industry requirements, and regulatory contexts.

Source: Accenture and Anthropic launch multi-year partnership to move enterprises from AI pilots to production

Johari Window Model and Four-Quadrant Analysis of Human–AI Dialogue

Dec 1, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction to the Johari Window Model and Its Four Quadrants

Section titled “Introduction to the Johari Window Model and Its Four Quadrants”

The Johari Window is a psychological model for improving self-awareness and interpersonal communication, proposed by psychologists Joseph Luft and Harrington Ingham in 1955. It divides personal cognition into four quadrants (or four “windows”):

  • Open Area (开放区): Information known to both yourself and others—public behaviors, attitudes, and traits. This is the “you know, I know” domain.

  • Blind Area (盲区): Information others can see but you overlook, such as behavioral traits apparent to others that you yourself don’t notice. This corresponds to “you know, I don’t”, i.e., your cognitive blind spots.

  • Hidden Area (隐藏区): Private information you know but others do not, like personal privacy or inner thoughts. This is the “you don’t know, I know” domain, also called the privacy zone.

  • Unknown Area (未知区): Potential information or traits unknown to both you and others, including untapped potential. This corresponds to the “you don’t know, I don’t” fully unknown domain.

The core idea is to expand the open area, reduce the blind and hidden areas, and explore the unknown area to enhance self-awareness and communication.

Mapping the Four Quadrants to Human–AI Dialogue

Section titled “Mapping the Four Quadrants to Human–AI Dialogue”

When mapping the Johari Window to human–AI dialogue, we can treat “self” as the human user and “other” as the AI system. The axes of “knowing/not knowing” become “whether the human knows” and “whether the AI knows.” The Johari quadrants are redefined in this context to frame human–machine conversations. The schematic below illustrates the correspondence:

A quadrant diagram of the Johari Window applied to human–AI dialogue. The horizontal axis indicates whether the AI has the information (right = AI knows), and the vertical axis indicates whether the human has the information (top = human doesn’t). Each quadrant reflects a different human–machine cognition setup: both know (open area), AI knows but the human doesn’t (blind area), the human knows but AI doesn’t (hidden area), and neither knows (unknown area).

Specifically, the four quadrants in human–AI dialogue mean:

  • Open Area (human knows + AI knows): Information or context is transparent to both parties. Both share the same knowledge base and clear task premises—akin to a public knowledge domain.

  • Blind Area (human doesn’t know + AI knows): The AI holds information the user lacks. The user’s question is their blind spot, but the AI may have relevant knowledge or skills to provide an answer the user doesn’t know.

  • Hidden Area (human knows + AI doesn’t): The user holds information the AI lacks, such as personal background, private data, or specialized knowledge. If not provided, the AI operates with missing context.
