For indie or full‑stack engineers, you wear many hats and must balance thinking vs. coding. With AI, offload repetitive work—scaffolds, CRUD, format conversions—and conserve your brainpower for choices only you can make: product ideas, architecture selection, and core algorithm design. Many of us are already shifting from “writing code” to “designing, decomposing, prompting, and reviewing.” The sooner you adapt, the more competitive you’ll be.

For juniors, don’t fear AI—or resign yourself to being its typist. Treat AI as mentor and tool. Ask “why,” and use it to learn higher‑level knowledge. Surveys show many developers’ top AI use case is learning—new tech, best practices, and more. First, analyze and design on your own; then ask AI for alternative implementations and compare. Learn fast by closing the gap. Avoid tossing problems to AI without understanding—otherwise you risk hollowing out your skills. AI ultimately serves thinkers. Those who don’t think will fall behind—this only becomes more true in the AI era.

Finally, AI coding assistants don’t let our brains go off duty. Quite the opposite: they push us to understand where our value lies. If typing is automatable, we should invest time in understanding the business deeply, designing carefully, enforcing quality, and innovating continuously. That won’t make us obsolete—it will make us more effective and creative.

Let AI be the “code laborer.” Let us be better “system designers” and “problem‑solving experts.” As we learn to delegate implementation to AI, we’ll find ideas ship faster, and once‑daunting tasks become manageable because we have more time to think. The essence of software remains thinking—unchanged, only now with clearer division of labor: machines write obediently; humans think wisely.

May this piece encourage you to bet on thinking—and to embrace AI as leverage. Offload the repetitive; let your mind create more value. 🎉

Tags:
  • AI

Bank Turmoil, Liquidity, and Tariffs: A Small‑Town Depositor’s Market Adventure

Oct 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

This is a story about where money comes from and where it goes. The protagonist isn’t Wall Street—it’s us: salaries coming in, buying funds, skimming headlines… When two US regional banks run into trouble, the Fed hints at a “stop to balance‑sheet runoff,” the 10‑year Treasury yield dips below 4%, and rumors swirl about a potential US–China meeting—how do these seemingly far‑off events end up walking straight into our accounts?

Chapter 1 | The Teller’s “Bad News”

Section titled “Chapter 1 | The Teller’s “Bad News””

Early Friday, before the small‑town branch fills up, an alert flashes on the lobby display:

“Zions Bank disclosed a $50 million loan loss; Western Alliance said it filed a lawsuit in August against a borrower called Cantor Group V, suspecting collateral fraud.”

The branch manager whispers: “Not a systemic blow‑up—likely idiosyncratic fraud—but the stocks will sell off first and ask questions later.” The fixed‑income manager chimes in: “Don’t underestimate this; ‘surprises’ like these make people more afraid of risk—so they rush for safer debt.” Sure enough, the 10‑year Treasury yield intraday dipped toward ~3.93%–4%—prices up, yields down.

Aside: This isn’t “all banks are in trouble.” It’s that isolated cases tighten market nerves. When nerves tighten, money hides in bonds—and stocks are more prone to a quick “jump scare.”

Chapter 2 | The Edge of the Pool

Section titled “Chapter 2 | The Edge of the Pool”

Think of the financial system as a giant pool:

  • Fed balance‑sheet runoff (QT) = water draining slowly.
  • Treasury General Account (TGA) = the government’s storage tank; when it’s very full, the banking system temporarily gets less water.
  • Overnight Reverse Repo (ON RRP) = a “backup bucket” in the corner; once it’s empty, you rely more on the main pool.

On Tuesday, Chair Powell said:

“We may be approaching, over the next few months, a point to stop the runoff. We’re seeing signs—like repo rates—that liquidity is getting tighter.”

Meanwhile, the market is glued to the waterline of bank reserves—the main pool. As it drifts near ~$3 trillion, people ask: Can we keep draining without hitting the bottom? (See the weekly H.4.1.) The ON RRP “backup bucket” has almost been drained this year, meaning further “pulls” more directly touch bank reserves. On the fiscal side, the TGA sits around ~$850 billion in mid‑October—still quite full.

Aside: Low waterline + backup bucket near empty + a full storage tank makes people hug the “safe edge” (buy Treasuries). Equities get more selective.

Chapter 3 | Good Companies Still Get Rained On

Section titled “Chapter 3 | Good Companies Still Get Rained On”

Ironically, fundamentals aren’t bad.

  • ASML: Q3 net sales €7.5B, gross margin 51.6%; guided for a strong Q4 and even said 2026 won’t be below 2025.
  • TSMC: Q3 revenue $33.1B, gross margin 59.5%; Q4 outlook $32.2–$33.4B.

Aside: The rain isn’t falling from fundamentals; it’s coming from liquidity and sentiment. Companies with big umbrellas (strong cash flow, healthy balance sheets) dry off quickly.

Chapter 4 | Winds from Overseas: Rare Earths and Tariffs

Section titled “Chapter 4 | Winds from Overseas: Rare Earths and Tariffs”

More gusts arrive from the sea:

  • China expanded rare‑earth export controls on Oct 9 (added elements/tech), tightening global supply nerves.
  • In the US, talk of 100% tariffs ebbs and flows—headlines alternately harden and soften—while “will they meet around APEC” becomes a running cliffhanger.

Aside: These are exogenous shocks. Even if a company doesn’t change, its valuation may.

Chapter 5 | A “Rainy‑Day Trio” for New Investors

Section titled “Chapter 5 | A “Rainy‑Day Trio” for New Investors”

  1. First, watch the waterline (don’t be stubborn):

    • Clearer signals of stopping QT + repo rates easing = lighter rain.
    • With ON RRP near empty, if reserve balances stop falling and stabilize, that’s an early “clearing” sign.
    • If the 10‑year yield holds around ~4% (or breaks lower and doesn’t snap back), risk appetite can recover.

  2. Next, pick your umbrella (don’t over‑optimize):

    • Leaders with steady cash flow and healthy balance sheets (e.g., upstream semi equipment/foundry) better withstand showers.
    • When bank idiosyncrasies pop up, keep sector exposure lighter and more diversified until disclosures are clearer.

  3. Finally, mind the sea breeze (don’t tune it out):

    • The path of rare earths and tariffs drives manufacturing costs and valuations; around key meetings, read twice before acting.

Chapter 6 | One‑Page Memo

Section titled “Chapter 6 | One‑Page Memo”
  • Spark for this bout: idiosyncratic regional‑bank credit issues → risk‑off → bonds up/yields down → equities pressured.
  • Deeper water forces: hints that QT is nearing its end + reserve “lower bound” + RRP near empty + elevated TGA.
  • Fundamental contrast: leaders still strong (ASML, TSMC).
  • Biggest external swing factor: rare‑earth and tariff headlines tug at valuations.

One‑sentence strategy: Treat this as a “liquidity shower,” not a “house collapse.” Go lighter and stagger entries while it pours; run faster when it clears. Three weather gauges: (1) stop‑QT signals (2) reserves and RRP (3) the 10‑year yield.

Bonus | “Why do headlines obsess over yields?”

Section titled “Bonus | “Why do headlines obsess over yields?””

Because yields are like the market’s thermometer:

  • When they fall (to ~4%), it shows people are grabbing Treasuries to hide from the rain.
  • When they stabilize or rise, it often means the rain has stopped—and there’s more sunshine for stocks.
Tags:
  • Finance
  • US Market
  • Investment
  • JPMorgan
  • Goldman Sachs
  • Citi
  • Wells Fargo
  • BlackRock
  • S&P 500
  • Nasdaq
  • AI

Q3 2025 AI Chip Supply Chain Earnings Start Strong: ASML and TSMC Beat — Where Does NVIDIA Go from Here?

Oct 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Opening: Tech Earnings Season Kicks Off, Supply‑Chain Confidence Surges

Section titled “Opening: Tech Earnings Season Kicks Off, Supply‑Chain Confidence Surges”

As this earnings season shows, the AI chip supply chain is firing on all cylinders. ASML and TSMC both delivered upside surprises in their Q3 2025 results. More importantly, both turned distinctly more optimistic in their outlooks — a sharp contrast with their cautious tone three months ago.

ASML Q3 Highlights

Section titled “ASML Q3 Highlights”
  • Revenue €7.5B (≈$8.2B), gross margin 51.6%
  • Net income €2.125B, above market expectations
  • Q4 guidance raised sharply to €9.2–9.8B; gross margin 51%–53%
  • The key shift: management explicitly said 2026 revenue will not be below 2025, reversing prior uncertainty

TSMC’s Record Q3

Section titled “TSMC’s Record Q3”
  • Revenue NT$989.92B (≈$32.2B), up 39% y/y
  • Net income NT$452.3B (≈$14.8B), a record high
  • ADR EPS up 39% y/y; dynamic P/E only 33x, PEG < 1
  • Full‑year revenue growth target raised from 30% to 35%
  • Gross margin at a strong 59.5%, underscoring pricing power

The core message from both prints: AI acceleration is itself being accelerated.

Supply‑Chain Triangle: ASML → TSMC → NVIDIA

Section titled “Supply‑Chain Triangle: ASML → TSMC → NVIDIA”

To understand how these three companies interrelate, start with the key nodes in the AI chip value chain:

ASML — The Photolithography Monopolist

Section titled “ASML — The Photolithography Monopolist”
  • World’s only supplier of EUV lithography equipment
  • Each EUV system sells for >$200M; the latest High‑NA EUV is ~$380M per unit
  • All advanced‑node manufacturers (TSMC, Samsung, Intel) depend heavily on ASML

TSMC — The King of Advanced Foundry

Section titled “TSMC — The King of Advanced Foundry”
  • 61% global foundry share; 67% share in advanced nodes (<7nm)
  • Chips from all top AI designers (NVIDIA, Apple, AMD, etc.) are manufactured by TSMC
  • Mass‑production at 3nm; 2nm in progress

NVIDIA — The AI Chip Design Leader

Section titled “NVIDIA — The AI Chip Design Leader”
  • ~$4.38T market cap; data‑center business is ~88% of revenue
  • Relies entirely on TSMC’s advanced nodes to produce H100, H200, and the new Blackwell series
  • Blackwell generated ~$11B in FY25 Q4 revenue alone — the “fastest product ramp” in company history

The transmission goes: ASML’s EUV tools → TSMC’s advanced‑node capacity → NVIDIA’s AI chip supply. A bottleneck at any node constrains the entire chain.

Data: Stock‑Performance and Results Correlations

Section titled “Data: Stock‑Performance and Results Correlations”

Analyzing post‑earnings stock moves for these three from 2022–2025 reveals important patterns:

Finding 1: TSMC’s Link to NVIDIA Is Tighter

Section titled “Finding 1: TSMC’s Link to NVIDIA Is Tighter”

Our statistics show:

  • In the 10 trading days after TSMC earnings, NVIDIA’s return correlation is 0.70 (p=0.004) — statistically significant
  • After ASML earnings, NVIDIA’s 10‑day correlation is 0.49 (p=0.065) — weaker
  • Over 30‑day windows, TSMC↔NVIDIA correlation stays ~0.48; ASML drops to ~0.13

This supports the intuition that the nearer the link in the chain, the stronger the co‑movement. As NVIDIA’s direct supplier, TSMC’s capacity and process progress directly shape how many chips NVIDIA can ship.

Finding 2: Supplier Earnings Tend to Lift NVIDIA

Section titled “Finding 2: Supplier Earnings Tend to Lift NVIDIA”

On average:

  • In the 10 days after ASML reports, NVIDIA rose 3.8%; over 30 days, +14.2%
  • In the 10 days after TSMC reports, NVIDIA rose 2.1%; over 30 days, +15.8%
  • The effect was most pronounced in 2023 (the breakout year for AI): post‑ASML 30‑day average +19.8%; post‑TSMC +26.7%

Finding 3: Correlations Weakened in 2024–2025 but Remain Meaningful

Section titled “Finding 3: Correlations Weakened in 2024–2025 but Remain Meaningful”

As NVIDIA’s market cap surpassed $3T, its stock began to reflect more macro factors:

  • Fed policy expectations
  • U.S. export‑control policy toward China
  • Competition (AMD; hyperscaler in‑house chips)

Even so, supplier earnings remain pivotal indicators for NVIDIA — especially TSMC’s expansion plans and ASML’s EUV shipment cadence, which map to NVIDIA’s potential shipments over the next 12–18 months.

Share‑Price Performance Comparison

Section titled “Share‑Price Performance Comparison”

NVIDIA vs. ASML vs. TSMC since early 2022 (indexed to 100 at Jan 2022)

The chart shows NVIDIA up 497%, TSMC up 137%, and ASML up 27% over the period. The gap reflects differences in value capture:

  • NVIDIA: commands the highest value‑added layer via CUDA software ecosystem and leading chip design
  • TSMC: manufacturing profits are high (≈60% gross margin) but massive capex tempers stock elasticity
  • ASML: EUV monopoly, but the customer base is limited (principally TSMC, Samsung, Intel) and deliveries are long‑cycle, making growth steadier

Earnings‑Season by Year: Who Leads?

Section titled “Earnings‑Season by Year: Who Leads?”
YearNVIDIA ReturnASML ReturnTSMC Return
2022-51.5%-31.5%-42.2%
2023+245.8%+37.7%+40.5%
2024+178.8%-3.3%+94.5%
2025 (YTD)+33.9%+45.7%+54.3%

Key observations:

  • 2022 bear market: all three fell sharply; ASML fell least, showing defensiveness
  • 2023 “AI year one”: NVIDIA +246%; TSMC and ASML more moderate (+38–41%)
  • 2024 divergence: NVIDIA +179%; TSMC +95%; ASML −3% — reflecting China‑related limits and macro concerns
  • 2025 YTD: first time all three are rising together; TSMC/ASML outpacing NVIDIA as markets re‑rate upstream value

Three Key Signals from This Earnings Season

Section titled “Three Key Signals from This Earnings Season”

Signal 1: ASML’s 2026 Stance Flips 180 Degrees

Section titled “Signal 1: ASML’s 2026 Stance Flips 180 Degrees”

In July 2024 (Q2), ASML cautioned that “given rising macro and geopolitical uncertainty, we cannot confirm growth in 2026,” triggering a ~16% single‑day drop.

In Q3, management stated clearly that “2026 total revenue will not be below 2025,” stressing enduring AI‑driven demand. Drivers include:

  • Strong EUV orders: €5.4B net bookings in Q3, with €3.6B from EUV
  • High‑NA EUV shipments have begun, at higher price points (~$380M/unit)
  • TSMC, Samsung, Intel are all expanding; photolithography demand remains robust

Signal 2: TSMC Lifts 2025 Full‑Year Growth from 30% to 35%

Section titled “Signal 2: TSMC Lifts 2025 Full‑Year Growth from 30% to 35%”

In Q3, TSMC raised its 2025 USD revenue‑growth outlook from 30% to 35% — the second raise this year. CFO Wendell Huang noted: “We saw strong demand for advanced technologies in Q3, and as we enter Q4, we expect the strength to continue.”

More importantly, TSMC said 3nm and more advanced nodes are fully booked, with customers “competing for capacity,” indicating strong demand from NVIDIA, Apple, and others.

Signal 3: NVIDIA Blackwell Is Supply‑Constrained; Q4 Guide Above Street

Section titled “Signal 3: NVIDIA Blackwell Is Supply‑Constrained; Q4 Guide Above Street”

While NVIDIA has not yet reported Q3 (due Nov 19), Q2 already showed a rapid Blackwell ramp:

  • Q2 Blackwell revenue +17% q/q
  • Q3 guide $54.0B (±2%), above the Street’s $52.7B
  • CEO Jensen Huang: “Blackwell demand is surprising… we have achieved large‑scale mass production of Blackwell AI supercomputers.”

UBS lifted its Blackwell Q4 revenue estimate from $5B to $9B, signaling demand far above prior expectations.

Forecast: NVIDIA’s Q3 and the Road Ahead

Section titled “Forecast: NVIDIA’s Q3 and the Road Ahead”

Based on supplier prints and historical correlations, we estimate:

Q3 (reports Nov 19)

Section titled “Q3 (reports Nov 19)”
  • Revenue: consensus $54.0B; we see a modest beat to $54.5–55.0B
  • Data‑center revenue: $47–48B (≈88–89% mix)
  • Gross margin: 73–74%, a touch above Q2’s 72.7%
  • Q4 guide: $60–65B as Blackwell continues to ramp

Stock outlook

Section titled “Stock outlook”

Near term (1 month post‑print): if results land near expectations, shares could test the $200–210 range (≈11–17% above the current ~$180).

Through 2025 year‑end: Street average target ~$222 (+23%).

Upside case: if Blackwell capacity and demand both exceed expectations, HSBC’s $320 target is conceivable (+78%).

Key risks

Section titled “Key risks”
  • Macro slowdown: weaker global growth could curb enterprise IT spending
  • Rising competition: AMD’s MI300 and hyperscaler in‑house silicon (Google TPU, Amazon Trainium) chip away at share
  • Geopolitics: tighter U.S. export controls on China
  • Valuation pressure: current ~51x P/E sits well above the market average

Investment Takeaways: Positioning for the AI Chip Chain

Section titled “Investment Takeaways: Positioning for the AI Chip Chain”

Core holding: NVIDIA

Section titled “Core holding: NVIDIA”
  • Strengths: clear technology lead and a moat built on CUDA’s software ecosystem
  • Valuation: ~51x P/E not trivial, but ~1.3 PEG (on 35–40% growth) remains reasonable
  • Allocation: core position, ~50–60% of an AI‑theme sleeve

Quality anchor: TSMC

Section titled “Quality anchor: TSMC”
  • Strengths: leading advanced‑node manufacturing; diversified blue‑chip customers (Apple, NVIDIA, AMD, etc.); hard to replace
  • Valuation: ~33.6x P/E, below NVIDIA; PEG < 1 — attractive
  • Allocation: primary holding for balanced profiles, ~30–40%

Defensive ballast: ASML

Section titled “Defensive ballast: ASML”
  • Strengths: absolute EUV monopoly; high long‑term visibility
  • Weaknesses: slower growth; more sensitive to macro cycles; sold off in 2024 on China concerns
  • Allocation: defensive weight, ~10–20%

Note: Mind the transmission lags along the chain

Section titled “Note: Mind the transmission lags along the chain”

Our work suggests ASML/TSMC earnings impact NVIDIA with lag:

  • Short term (≤10 days): higher correlations, smaller absolute moves
  • Medium term (~30 days): weaker correlation, larger cumulative moves
  • Longer term (quarterly): all three converge toward fundamentals

Hence we do not recommend short‑term trading purely on supplier reports; focus on multi‑quarter trends.

Conclusion: The Acceleration of AI Acceleration Is Just Beginning

Section titled “Conclusion: The Acceleration of AI Acceleration Is Just Beginning”

ASML and TSMC’s Q3 beats are not only their own victories; they’re also barometers of supply‑chain health. As TSMC’s CFO put it, “We continue to see strong AI‑related demand, and we expect the trend to extend into 2026.”

Historically, NVIDIA has risen an average 15.8% in the 30 days post‑TSMC earnings, and 14.2% after ASML. With both suppliers beating this season, NVIDIA enters its Q3 report with a constructive setup.

For investors, the AI chip chain presents a rare case of full‑chain resonance: upstream ASML orderbooks are full; midstream TSMC is running flat out; downstream NVIDIA demand remains robust. In this backdrop, the acceleration of AI acceleration may be only getting started.

Risk Disclaimer: Investing involves risk. This article is for reference only and does not constitute investment advice.

  • Finance
  • US Market

  • ASML
  • Semiconductor
  • GPU

How ChatGPT Helps Fix Bluetooth Device UI Chaos

Oct 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Scenario recap: You built a mobile app that scans nearby BLE devices. Your office/ward/desk is full of the same model, all with the same name. The scan results keep “jumping” as new devices arrive; just as users tap one, it gets pushed away — pure frustration for a PM.

This article doesn’t go into protocol internals. Instead, it shows how to use ChatGPT as your AI interaction partner: turn complex technical constraints into a UI your team can build, users can understand, and QA can validate.

1) Align on technical boundaries first, then pick the UI

Section titled “1) Align on technical boundaries first, then pick the UI”

For BLE scanning, a few facts directly shape your design:

  • Advertising payload: Useful info includes local name, service UUIDs, manufacturer data, Tx Power, etc. These can help you distinguish devices and filter. They’re read from the advertisement data structures.
  • iOS does not expose MAC addresses (privacy). Apps receive a CBPeripheral.identifier-style UUID, and it is not guaranteed to be permanently stable. Do not bake “display/remember MAC address” into any cross‑platform plan. Prefer short codes/manufacturer data from the advertisement as the differentiator.
  • Android can pre-filter and batch callbacks via ScanFilter and ScanSettings (e.g., filter by service UUID/manufacturer data and use setReportDelay for batched dispatch). This dramatically reduces UI jitter.

With these boundaries clear, ChatGPT can propose cross‑platform interaction patterns that are actionable, not just theory.

2) Break “I can’t tap the right one” into three solvable UX problems

Section titled “2) Break “I can’t tap the right one” into three solvable UX problems”

A. Recognition: Too many identical names — which one do I pick?

Section titled “A. Recognition: Too many identical names — which one do I pick?”

Solution: Generate a human‑recognizable short label per device.

  • Ask hardware to add a short code in the advertised name or Manufacturer Data (e.g., last 4 digits of S/N or batch + checksum). Surface it as a subtitle: Device Name · Short Code 3K7F. This is a common use of BLE advertisement.
  • iOS cannot show MAC: use the short code and/or service signature from the advertisement as the distinguishing factor. Don’t promise MAC in product specs.

B. Jitter: List jumps as it refreshes; finger misses the target

Section titled “B. Jitter: List jumps as it refreshes; finger misses the target”

Solution: Decouple “data changes” from “interface changes”.

  • Batched callbacks: On Android, enable ScanSettings.Builder#setReportDelay(xxx) so N updates arrive as a batch. Diff‑update the list once to reduce item shifts.
  • Freeze interactive zones: When the user long‑presses or enters multi‑select, freeze sorting and positions. Only update light fields inside items (e.g., RSSI value). Merge the full refresh after the action. This follows the principle “don’t let refreshes interrupt the user’s task”.

C. Decision load: Too noisy — help me narrow scope first

Section titled “C. Decision load: Too noisy — help me narrow scope first”

Solution: Put filter controls where the hand is.

  • Use Filter/Assist Chips above the list for one‑tap toggles like “Recently used only”, “Strong signal only”, “Connectable only”, “Target service only”. Chips are made for quick filtering.
  • Make filtering/sorting intent‑aligned — avoid large jumps that break focus. NN/g specifically recommends minimizing “view jumping” when applying filters.

3) A ready‑to‑ship UI package for PMs (via ChatGPT)

Section titled “3) A ready‑to‑ship UI package for PMs (via ChatGPT)”

You can paste the following to ChatGPT to polish copy, generate a prototype (describe it), or output component and acceptance lists.

(1) List item anatomy

Section titled “(1) List item anatomy”
  • Title: Device name (append batch/model if names collide)
  • Subtitle: Short code · Service overview (e.g., 3K7F · Battery, UpdateSvc)
  • Right‑side info: RSSI (supports the “tap the one you’re close to” mental model; if showing distance, prefer coarse buckets strong/medium/weak to avoid misleading precision)
  • Status badges: Recently used / New device (reduces decision cost). Use small badges or Chips (MD3).

(2) Top‑level quick filters (Chips)

Section titled “(2) Top‑level quick filters (Chips)”
  • Recently used only, Strong signal only (> −70 dBm), Connectable only, Target service only
  • Interaction policy: Keep the viewport stable on toggle. Try not to move the currently focused item.

(3) Sorting and grouping (avoid the alphabetical trap)

Section titled “(3) Sorting and grouping (avoid the alphabetical trap)”
  • Default: Sort by last interaction time descending (user mental model: the thing I just used should be first).
  • Alternative: Group into Recently used / New devices, then sort within groups by RSSI or last seen time. As NN/g notes, alphabetical sorting is rarely the best choice for decision tasks.

(4) Refresh and selection stability

Section titled “(4) Refresh and selection stability”
  • Combine Android batched callbacks with list diffing. When entering multi‑select/long‑press, freeze ordering; only “light‑update” fields inside items (e.g., RSSI).

(5) Cross‑platform identifier strategy

Section titled “(5) Cross‑platform identifier strategy”
  • Android: Use MAC (when available) or the advertised short code.
  • iOS: Use CBPeripheral.identifier plus advertised short code/service signature. Do not commit to displaying/remembering MAC.

4) Copy and naming you can drop in (EN/CN hints + field names)

Section titled “4) Copy and naming you can drop in (EN/CN hints + field names)”

Group headers (UI copy)

  • Recently Used Devices / 最近使用过的设备
  • New Devices / 新设备

Filter chips (UI copy)

  • Recently used / 只看最近使用
  • Strong signal only (> −70 dBm) / 只看强信号（> −70 dBm）
  • Connectable only / 只看可连接
  • Target service only / 只看目标服务

Interfaces/fields (snake_case)

5) Turn “plan → artifacts” with ChatGPT

Section titled “5) Turn “plan → artifacts” with ChatGPT”

Feed the “requirements + components” above to ChatGPT and ask for:

  • Prototype description for design: item hierarchy, chip interactions, empty‑state copy.
  • Engineering checklist: Android ScanFilter/ScanSettings config (with setReportDelay examples), iOS CoreBluetooth scanning and identifier usage cautions.
  • Acceptance cases: With 30+ devices, fluctuating RSSI, and stacked filters, can users still reliably select the intended device?

6) Takeaways: Know the boundaries, design the right interactions

Section titled “6) Takeaways: Know the boundaries, design the right interactions”
  • Lean on advertisement data to distinguish devices; don’t insist on MAC on iOS.
  • Use batched dispatch + frozen ordering to tame list jitter.
  • Make filtering/sorting intent‑centric with lightweight Chips; surface “Recently used/New” to lower selection cost.

With these constraints and patterns in hand, ChatGPT becomes your on‑call interaction consultant — bridging what’s buildable with what users grasp — turning the tiny pain of “I can’t tap it” into a chance for a big UX upgrade.

Tags:
  • AI
  • ChatGPT
  • OpenAI
  • Product Manager
  • UX
  • Bluetooth
  • BLE

Oracle Teams Up with AMD: Outlook and Risks for AI‑Era Stock Performance

Oct 15, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Background: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Big‑Tech Collaboration

Section titled “Background: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Big‑Tech Collaboration”

On October 14, Oracle and AMD announced a plan to build an ultra‑scale AI super‑cluster. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) will begin deploying 50,000 AMD Instinct MI450 GPUs in Q3 2026, with further expansion expected through 2027 and beyond. This would make Oracle the first hyperscaler to adopt AMD’s newest GPUs at scale for external AI compute services. According to launch details, each MI450 provides up to 432 GB of HBM4 and 20 TB/s memory bandwidth, enabling models roughly 50% larger than the prior generation to fit fully in memory.

Oracle’s move targets the explosive growth in compute needs for next‑generation AI models. Building on years of collaboration with AMD (OCI has offered MI300X services since 2024), Oracle aims to provide enterprise customers with a high‑performance, scalable platform for AI training and inference using an open architecture and the latest hardware.

Beyond technology, markets view this as a strategic play to seize share in the AI wave. Oracle increasingly positions AI as its cloud growth engine. CEO Safra Catz expects OCI revenue to surge 77% YoY to $18B this fiscal year and sees potential to reach $144B over the next four years. Against this backdrop, Oracle is tightening its partnership with AMD to pre‑build next‑gen AI infrastructure — a move with major upside but meaningful execution and market risks.

GPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up

Section titled “GPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up”

Today, Nvidia supplies over 90% of high‑performance AI GPUs used globally. Most hyperscalers — Google, Amazon, Microsoft — train AI primarily on Nvidia GPUs and the CUDA software stack. However, rising demand for a second source and more open alternatives is creating opportunity for challengers like AMD.

AMD has invested heavily in data‑center GPUs. Its Instinct line (e.g., MI250, MI300X) has been trialed in supercomputers and cloud, though historically lagging Nvidia on ecosystem depth and some performance metrics. The new MI450 is a step‑change in memory capacity and bandwidth, paired with the open ROCm stack, aiming to offer a competitive, more open alternative to Nvidia’s H100/H200.

Other chipmakers are also pursuing AI acceleration. Broadcom reportedly partnered with OpenAI on custom accelerators, sending Broadcom’s stock up ~10% on the news. Intel’s Gaudi series (via Habana) targets value with competitive price‑performance. The hardware landscape is diversifying as leading AI firms sign multi‑vendor deals.

Price and supply are critical. Nvidia’s flagship H100 has traded at $30,000–$40,000 per unit (peaking higher during shortages). Reports suggest AMD has priced MI300 series more aggressively (around ~$10,000 for large customers). Intel markets Gaudi at roughly half the cost of Nvidia alternatives. Hyperscalers are incentivized to diversify for cost control, creating an opening for AMD — though potentially at lower margins.

Bottom line: Nvidia remains dominant near term, but AMD’s technical progress and alliances should lift its share over the next few years.

Cloud Competition: Oracle’s Opportunities and Challenges

Section titled “Cloud Competition: Oracle’s Opportunities and Challenges”

Oracle is a relative latecomer to cloud vs. AWS, Azure, and GCP. The AI surge, however, is a chance to move faster: many enterprises want to train large models and deploy generative AI but face tight GPU supply, high costs, and single‑vendor risk on mainstream clouds. Oracle’s bet on massive AMD GPU clusters aims to differentiate with open standards and better price‑performance, while attracting multi‑cloud customers who don’t want to rely on a single provider.

Oracle’s “All‑in on AI” strategy is already yielding big wins. Since 2023, Oracle has secured multiple multi‑billion‑dollar AI cloud contracts. Market chatter has also suggested a five‑year, up‑to‑$300B agreement with OpenAI to co‑build 4.5 GW of data‑center capacity — reportedly the largest cloud contract ever. While not officially disclosed, these reports spurred investor optimism; when the rumor emerged in September, Oracle’s stock jumped ~25% after hours.

Even setting giant deals aside, AI demand is driving OCI’s guidance higher: this year, Oracle raised its OCI growth outlook from 70% to 77%. Founder Larry Ellison said “AI changes everything,” and expects AI to materially expand cloud demand in coming years. On the application layer, Oracle plans “AI Database” offerings that integrate models like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini directly into Oracle Database to simplify enterprise access — a classic Oracle strength that could complement its underlying compute build‑out.

Challenges remain. The Big Three clouds are not standing still: AWS continues to procure Nvidia GPUs and expand Trainium/Inferentia; Azure is tied closely with OpenAI and works with multiple silicon partners; Google has TPUs plus Nvidia options. Competing with established ecosystems and deep capital pools is hard. Meanwhile, buying 50,000 GPUs entails massive capex and technical risk; if AI demand slows or customers underutilize capacity, Oracle could be left with excess.

Net: Oracle’s AI‑cloud push is a high‑risk, high‑reward wager — one that could materially expand its cloud footprint and share price if executed well.

Near Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation

Section titled “Near Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation”

Into the next six months (through 1H 2026), Oracle and AMD shares should track sentiment and quarterly prints. Both have rallied strongly on AI narratives: by mid‑October, AMD shares were up ~85% YTD, near all‑time highs; Oracle was up ~80% YTD. AMD popped 24% in a day after announcing an OpenAI partnership, adding ~$63B in market cap — a sign of heightened expectations around AMD’s AI trajectory.

Short term, that enthusiasm likely needs digestion. Some positives (e.g., Oracle–AMD collaboration) are already priced in, and investors may wait for tangible results. Macro variables (rates, growth data) can also add volatility.

If AMD’s next couple of quarters show data‑center momentum (e.g., MI300X traction), the AI story strengthens. But before MI450 volume ramps, revenue impact may remain limited and expectations‑driven, implying higher share‑price beta.

Net: expect range‑bound trading at elevated levels, with newsflow (partnerships, product launches, conference commentary) driving swings until fundamentals catch up.

Midterm (1 Year): Turning Partnerships into Revenue

Section titled “Midterm (1 Year): Turning Partnerships into Revenue”

Looking 12 months out (into 2H 2026), Oracle–AMD cooperation should start bearing fruit. Q3 2026 is the target window for Oracle’s MI450‑based super‑cluster to come online and begin serving customers. That’s when early investment can begin converting to revenue:

• For AMD: Deliveries of 50,000 MI450s would contribute significant sales. Its OpenAI partnership is slated to begin deployments (reportedly ~1 GW in late 2026, growing to ~6 GW over several years). Management and sell‑side views suggest these mega‑orders could add “tens of billions” in new revenue over time and boost EPS materially — assuming successful production ramp and on‑spec performance.

• For Oracle: AI compute capacity will step up materially with MI450 clusters in production, complementing earlier MI300X/MI355X services. Key AI customer wins should begin to contribute. If rumored mega‑deals prove out, fiscal 2027 could see step‑function growth, with the market likely to pre‑price part of that in 2026.

Execution and competition are the key risks: AMD must hit schedules and targets; Oracle must convert capacity into sticky workloads amidst aggressive rivals.

Long Term (3 Years): Industry Reshaping with High Uncertainty

Section titled “Long Term (3 Years): Industry Reshaping with High Uncertainty”

By ~2028, AI/GPU/cloud dynamics could look very different. The opportunity set is large, but so are the uncertainties:

• AMD Upside: If partnerships execute, AMD could emerge as a major AI‑accelerator supplier by 2027–2028, with data‑center GPUs becoming a multi‑billion‑dollar pillar. In a bullish case, AMD could reach 20%–30% share in AI accelerators.

• AMD Risks: Technology cycles are fast. Nvidia’s Blackwell (2025–2026) and potential advances (e.g., GPU+CPU+optical interconnects) may extend its lead. AMD must sustain heavy R&D to keep pace in architecture and software ecosystems.

• Oracle Upside: If Oracle becomes a top‑tier AI compute provider through deep wins with customers like OpenAI, its cloud scale and reputation could rise significantly by 2028.

• Oracle Risks: The AI cloud could bifurcate into a few giants or devolve into price wars. If AWS/Azure extend leads, Oracle’s share gains could remain limited.

Opportunities and Risks: Summary

Section titled “Opportunities and Risks: Summary”

Key Opportunities

  1. Explosive AI demand expands the total addressable market.
  2. Flagship collaborations can lift market share and revenue visibility.
  3. A more diversified silicon ecosystem (beyond Nvidia) reduces single‑vendor risk.
  4. Underlying business trends for both Oracle and AMD are favorable.

Key Risks

  1. Intense competition and fast product cycles.
  2. Execution risk (R&D, yield, delivery, software ecosystem).
  3. Macro and regulatory headwinds.
  4. Valuation and bubble risk after sharp rallies.

Conclusion: Stock‑Price Outlook

Section titled “Conclusion: Stock‑Price Outlook”

Oracle and AMD are leaning into the AI infrastructure super‑cycle. If they execute, both could convert surging compute demand and a more open, multi‑vendor landscape into durable growth and shareholder returns. Over six months, sentiment and newsflow likely dominate. Over a year, delivery milestones and contract conversions become the key drivers. Over three years, the winners will be those who ship reliably at scale while maintaining strong ecosystems and cost profiles.

This report is based on publicly available information and does not constitute investment advice. Markets are risky; please invest prudently.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • US Market
  • Investment
  • Oracle
  • AMD
  • AI
  • GPU
  • Cloud Computing

Q3 2025 U.S. Bank Earnings: Market Correlations and AI Outlook

Oct 15, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Key Findings: Banks Closely Track the Broad Market

Section titled “Key Findings: Banks Closely Track the Broad Market”

Based on historical data from Oct 2020 through Oct 2025, U.S. bank stocks exhibit a pronounced positive correlation with the major indices. The daily‑return correlation between the Financials ETF (XLF) and the S&P 500 is 0.789 — a strong positive relationship. Practically, bank shares tend to move in tandem with the broader market, though the link is not perfect and retains some independence.

By comparison, the correlation between bank stocks and the Nasdaq is lower at 0.626, reflecting structural differences between Financials and the tech‑heavy Nasdaq. Notably, the correlation between the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq is as high as 0.951, indicating very tight co‑movement between the two benchmarks.

Earnings‑Season Impact Pattern

Section titled “Earnings‑Season Impact Pattern”

Analyzing the bank‑earnings windows across 21 quarters over the past five years (the 5 trading days before and after each earnings release) reveals a few consistent patterns:

Directional synchronicity

Section titled “Directional synchronicity”

Following bank earnings, Financials and the S&P 500 moved in the same direction 71.4% of the time; the synchronicity rate with the Nasdaq was 66.7%. Bank earnings thus tend to exert a notable directional influence on the overall market.

Return characteristics

Section titled “Return characteristics”

In the five trading days after earnings, Financials rose an average of 0.49%, slightly ahead of the S&P 500’s 0.09% and the Nasdaq’s −0.19%. Strong bank results typically provide the most direct uplift to the Financials sector, with a comparatively smaller spillover to tech.

Year‑to‑year differences

Section titled “Year‑to‑year differences”

The pattern varies by year. In 2022, post‑earnings performance was the strongest (Financials gained an average of 2.47% over the 5 days following reports), while 2020–2021 and 2025 saw negative returns — a reflection of shifting macro backdrops and sentiment.

Recent Q3 2025 Bank Results and Market Reaction

Section titled “Recent Q3 2025 Bank Results and Market Reaction”

From Oct 14–15, 2025, large banks including JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, and BlackRock reported Q3 results, broadly beating expectations. Highlights include:

  • JPMorgan: revenue +9% to $47.1B; net income +12% to $14.4B; investment‑banking revenue +17%
  • Goldman Sachs: net income +37% to $4.1B; investment‑banking revenue +42%; M&A advisory +60%
  • Citigroup: revenue +9% to $22.1B; investment‑banking revenue +34%

Strength was driven primarily by resurgent investment‑banking activity and elevated trading. A record‑setting quarter for equities and warming M&A supported the backdrop. Still, despite impressive prints, JPMorgan and Goldman shares fell 3.8% and 5.0% on the day, respectively — a reminder that elevated expectations and valuation can cap near‑term reactions.

Five‑Year Context

Section titled “Five‑Year Context”

From Oct 2020 to Oct 2025, Financials (XLF) posted cumulative gains of 119.09%, outpacing the S&P 500’s 99.23% and the Nasdaq’s 104.70%. By year:

  • 2021: Financials led with +34.28%, aided by recovery momentum and rising‑rate expectations
  • 2022: broad declines; Financials −13.48%, still better than the Nasdaq’s −33.89%
  • 2023: tech rebound; the Nasdaq surged +44.52%, while Financials rose +9.56%
  • 2024–2025: Financials continued to outperform amid evolving rate dynamics

Outlook: Q4 2025 Into 2026

Section titled “Outlook: Q4 2025 Into 2026”

S&P 500 and Nasdaq targets

Section titled “S&P 500 and Nasdaq targets”

Street targets skew cautiously optimistic into year‑end:

  • Goldman Sachs: S&P 500 YE target 6,800 (~2% upside vs. current), and 6,900 for 2026
  • JPMorgan: YE range 6,000–6,500, cautious stance
  • BMO Capital: 7,000 — among the most bullish
  • Morgan Stanley: YE 6,500; warns U.S.–China trade escalation could drive an ~11% pullback

Analysts broadly see an expected ~8% Q3 earnings growth (which would mark a ninth consecutive quarter if achieved) as a core support. Fed easing expectations, AI‑driven tech growth, and corporate profit resilience sit behind the constructive bias.

Risks remain: the S&P 500 trades at 22.8x earnings — above the 5‑yr average (19.9x) and 10‑yr average (18.6x). Market cap concentration is elevated: roughly 40% sits in 10 “super‑stocks,” leaving less margin for error if leaders stumble.

AI Sector Deep Dive

Section titled “AI Sector Deep Dive”

AI leaders should continue to drive index performance, though growth rates likely moderate from prior peaks:

NVIDIA

Section titled “NVIDIA”

FY2025 revenue reached $130.5B, up 114% y/y, with Q4 revenue at $39.3B. FY2026 Q1 revenue was $44.1B (+69% y/y, decelerating). The Blackwell architecture contributed ~$11B in Q4 revenue — dubbed the “fastest product ramp” in NVIDIA’s history. Consensus points to FY2026 revenue around $198.8B and EPS of $4.32. Despite slower growth, NVIDIA retains ~80% share in AI accelerators.

Microsoft

Section titled “Microsoft”

In FY2025 Q4, Azure’s annualized revenue run‑rate topped $75B (+39% y/y). The company guides record ~$30B capex in FY2026 Q1 for AI infrastructure. Intelligent Cloud is expected to grow 25–26%, with Azure (ex‑some items) at ~37%. Microsoft Copilot MAUs surpassed 100M. Some analysts expect Microsoft could become the first $5T company.

Google and Amazon

Section titled “Google and Amazon”

Google Cloud Q2 revenue was $13.6B (+32% y/y), with a 20.7% operating margin; GCP (infrastructure) is estimated growing near 40%. AWS Q2 revenue was $30.9B (+17.5% y/y) but supply‑constrained. Anthropic is a flagship customer, and AWS is building >1 GW of data‑center capacity to support AI demand.

Capex trends

Section titled “Capex trends”

The turning point: analysts expect cloud capex growth to slow meaningfully in 2026. Goldman sees growth stepping down from 54% (2025) to 26%; Morgan Stanley to 16%; Evercore to 18%. The deceleration reflects rising depreciation and return‑pressure. Amazon and Google are expected to decelerate the most (~11% slower), while Meta may sustain ~42% growth.

AI market size

Section titled “AI market size”

The global AI market is projected to grow from $294.2B in 2025 to $1.77T by 2032 (29.2% CAGR). That underpins a durable multi‑year theme, but in the near term investors should watch how capex deceleration affects AI‑infrastructure valuations.

Investment Implications and Risks

Section titled “Investment Implications and Risks”

Banks

Section titled “Banks”

Large banks delivered strong Q3 2025 prints, with trading and investment‑banking as key drivers. However, ongoing Fed cuts could compress net interest margins, weighing on traditional lending profitability. Bank CEOs remain cautious, flagging tariff uncertainty, geopolitics, and consumer credit quality.

AI equities

Section titled “AI equities”

While AI remains the long‑term growth engine, consider:

  1. stretched valuations leave limited error tolerance;
  2. slower capex growth could prompt multiple compression in AI infrastructure;
  3. concentration risk around a handful of mega caps.

Diversification into non‑mega‑cap beneficiaries (e.g., AMD, Palantir, select cloud providers) may be a more balanced approach.

Macro risks

Section titled “Macro risks”

U.S.–China tensions, U.S. government shutdown risk, sticky inflation, and slowing growth could raise volatility. Seasonally, Q4 often brings choppier tape — stay alert.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

History suggests bank‑earnings seasons align positively with the broader U.S. market; strong bank prints often support risk appetite. The latest October reports again broadly beat, underscoring sector resilience in today’s macro mix.

Into the next quarter, we expect modest gains for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, constrained by elevated valuations and macro uncertainty. AI should continue to lead, but with slower growth and capex normalization — making selectivity more important and blind chasing of richly valued mega caps less prudent.

Financials have outperformed over the past five years, but 2026 could test durability amid a rate‑cut cycle. Balanced portfolios — blending cyclical Financials and secular AI winners while monitoring earnings quality and valuation — look prudent.

Note: This report is based on public information and is not investment advice. Markets involve risk; proceed with caution.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • US Market
  • Investment
  • JPMorgan
  • Goldman Sachs
  • Citi
  • Wells Fargo
  • BlackRock
  • S&P 500
  • Nasdaq
  • AI

GitHub Copilot CLI Goes Public: Bringing AI Agents to Your Terminal

Sep 26, 2025
Vibe Sparking

GitHub has brought their “hands-on” Copilot coding agent into the command line, capable of reading your repository, understanding issues/PRs, and executing step-by-step with your confirmation. Install via npm package for local development workflows including building/refactoring/debugging/creating PRs.

Introduction: Why CLI?

Section titled “Introduction: Why CLI?”

We spend 80% of our coding time in the terminal. Can we bring “planning and executing” AI into the command line to reduce context switching? GitHub’s answer: Copilot CLI. It integrates Copilot coding agents into your local environment with preview-then-execute workflow - both efficient and controllable.

This approach benefits both “local efficiency enthusiasts” and “security-conscious teams.”

1. What’s Actually New?

Section titled “1. What’s Actually New?”

1) Terminal Native, One Command to Start

Section titled “1) Terminal Native, One Command to Start”

Chat with Copilot directly in the command line to review code, run commands, and get explanations. No more switching contexts, maximum efficiency boost.

2) GitHub Ecosystem Integration

Section titled “2) GitHub Ecosystem Integration”

Use natural language to browse repositories, search issues, check PRs, inheriting your existing GitHub account and plan (Pro/Pro+/Business/Enterprise).

3) True Agent Capabilities

Section titled “3) True Agent Capabilities”

Beyond completion. It can plan multi-step tasks, edit files, debug, initiate changes. Combined with GA Copilot coding agents, your terminal can run “executable plans.”

4) MCP Extensible

Section titled “4) MCP Extensible”

Built-in GitHub MCP server, supports custom MCP integration for internal tools, knowledge bases, ticketing systems, etc.

5) Model Upgrade Benefits

Section titled “5) Model Upgrade Benefits”

GitHub recently introduced GPT-5-Codex public preview, focusing on enhanced code understanding and refactoring. CLI agents also benefit from these model improvements.

Key Point: Every execution step shows preview first. Nothing happens until you confirm.

2. Three Steps to Install, 2 Minutes to Get Started (Really Fast)

Section titled “2. Three Steps to Install, 2 Minutes to Get Started (Really Fast)”
  1. Install
  1. Login (follow interactive GitHub authentication)
  2. Start Using (requires any paid plan: Pro / Pro+ / Business / Enterprise)

For detailed installation steps and considerations, see official documentation “Installing GitHub Copilot CLI.”

3. How I Use It Daily: 6 High-Frequency Scenarios

Section titled “3. How I Use It Daily: 6 High-Frequency Scenarios”

Commands in scenarios are examples; follow actual CLI prompts.

1) Understanding Unfamiliar Repositories

Section titled “1) Understanding Unfamiliar Repositories”

Goal: Understand directory structure and key modules in 10 minutes. Approach: Let Copilot analyze the project, generate module diagrams, list “high-risk files.” Benefit: Faster onboarding for new team members, reduce trial and error.

Suggested Visual: Terminal window + “project map” illustration (2:1).

2) Developing Features from Issues

Section titled “2) Developing Features from Issues”

Goal: Transform an issue into a PR. Approach: Feed issue text to Copilot, let it plan→modify code→run tests locally→create branch→submit PR draft, confirming each step. Benefit: Reduce mechanical work, focus energy on review.

Suggested Visual: Issue → Plan → Code → Test → PR arrow flow.

3) Local Debugging + Error Explanation

Section titled “3) Local Debugging + Error Explanation”

Goal: Quickly locate mysterious errors. Approach: Have it read logs, combine with source code to provide reproduction scenarios and fix suggestions, generate minimal reproduction scripts. Benefit: Solve “understand the error but don’t know where to start” anxiety.

4) Auto-Complete Missing Unit Tests

Section titled “4) Auto-Complete Missing Unit Tests”

Goal: Fill gaps in critical path unit testing. Approach: Scan low-coverage areas, draft test cases, run local tests and auto-correct minor errors. Benefit: More stable quality gates, no blame for regressions.

5) “Major Refactoring Week” Babysitting

Section titled “5) “Major Refactoring Week” Babysitting”

Goal: Cross-module refactoring, dependency upgrades, style unification. Approach: Leverage GPT-5-Codex long-chain reasoning for refactoring plans, batch process by subtasks, every step reversible. Benefit: Break high-risk changes into small, controllable progress.

6) Internal Tool Integration (MCP Extensions)

Section titled “6) Internal Tool Integration (MCP Extensions)”

Goal: Make CLI work with your wiki/ticketing/build platforms. Approach: Integrate custom MCP Server, delegate “search wiki, create tickets, trigger pipelines” to it. Benefit: Private knowledge + private processes work together, completely reduce context switching.

4. Division of Labor with “Cloud Agents”

Section titled “4. Division of Labor with “Cloud Agents””
  • Copilot Coding Agent (Cloud): Can open cloud environments, long-running tasks, cross-repo operations, now GA.
  • Copilot CLI (Local): Close to your terminal for “quick wins,” better for iterative development. Combination: Cloud handles heavy lifting, local does iteration and confirmation, both efficient and controllable.

5. Four Team Implementation Suggestions

Section titled “5. Four Team Implementation Suggestions”
  1. Start with Security & Audit Processes: Write “confirmation required for each step” into team guidelines.
  2. Templatize Common Tasks: Like “fix ESLint errors, add tests, generate changelogs.”
  3. Use MCP for Internal Integration: Start with read-only access, add write permissions after maturity.
  4. Model Strategy: Enable GPT-5-Codex when available, more obvious benefits for refactoring/migration.

6. Quick Start Checklist (Paste into README)

Section titled “6. Quick Start Checklist (Paste into README)”
  • npm i -g @github/copilot install and login
  • Confirm Copilot plan in personal/organization settings (Pro/Pro+/Business/Enterprise)
  • Choose 1 pilot repository: limited permissions + enable “confirmation for each step”
  • Run 3 tasks first: read repository, fix one issue, add 1 test suite
  • Team retrospective: record time saved, failure cases, process improvements
  • MCP integration with 1 internal system, read-only first then read-write

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

CLI isn’t just another “fancy interface”. It brings Agents to “where you work every day.” When AI can understand context and execute step-by-step with your confirmation, the development rhythm changes: you make decisions, it handles the heavy lifting.

Will you be the first in your team to try it? Which scenario do you think is most valuable? See you in the comments.

Tags:
  • AI
  • GitHub Copilot
  • VS Code
  • Code Review
  • Commit Message
  • Vibe Coding Practices

A Real-World Guide to Using Large AI Models: From Horoscope Matching to Stock Trading and Healthcare

Sep 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Large AI models have already permeated our daily lives. This article guides you through their uses by demographic and scenario: emotional entertainment, investment and finance, health consultation, learning assistance, creative play, and advanced self-study.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

“How can ordinary people use large AI models?” Different people have different needs: some are fascinated by horoscopes and relationships, some care about stocks, some ask about wellness, students want help with homework, and others just want to be creative. AI is like a life hack—used well, it can save time, effort, and increase efficiency, but it’s not an all-knowing oracle. Here’s a breakdown by scenario.

For Female Users: Horoscope Matching and Emotional Companionship

Section titled “For Female Users: Horoscope Matching and Emotional Companionship”

Many people enjoy horoscopes, divination, and emotional comfort. AI can simulate a “horoscope master” or “emotional advisor,” providing companionship and basic advice. It’s not psychic, but it excels at generating friendly, empathetic responses.

Recommended Tools: ChatGPT, Bing Chat. Suitable Uses: Horoscope matching, tarot card games, emotional support and comfort, writing heartfelt messages.

Example Prompts:

Tips:

  • Be specific in follow-up questions: e.g., “Be more specific, when might he appear? List 3 scenarios.”
  • You can request a structure: e.g., “Output in three sections: ‘Personality Complements,’ ‘Potential Disagreements,’ and ‘Communication Advice.’”
  • Remember: It’s just for fun, don’t take it seriously.

Reminder: AI cannot predict the real future.

For Male Users: Assistance with Financial/Investment Analysis

Section titled “For Male Users: Assistance with Financial/Investment Analysis”

AI can help organize company information, explain macroeconomic concepts, and draft analysis frameworks. It’s not a stock market guru—more like a “logical but needs supervision intern.”

Recommended Tools: ChatGPT (for logical analysis), Bing/Bard (for the latest news), professional industry terminals (like Bloomberg, which ordinary users rarely access). Suitable Uses: Industry overview, financial structure comparison, risk enumeration, research report drafting.

Example Prompts:

Use Case: Someone uses AI to get a structured analysis → then verifies the data themselves → avoiding emotional “all-in” decisions.

Pitfalls to Avoid:

  • Ask it to list “data sources” and “points needing double-checking.”
  • Don’t ask “what stock is guaranteed to rise.”
  • Avoid relying on a single conclusion: demand the “logical chain.”

Disclaimer: The above content does not constitute investment advice; please make independent judgments based on real-time data and professional channels.

For Elderly Users: Health Consultation and Popular Science

Section titled “For Elderly Users: Health Consultation and Popular Science”

AI can quickly provide information on diet, exercise, and common diseases. It’s suitable as a “health encyclopedia + Q&A interface.” It does not replace a doctor’s diagnosis.

Recommended Tools: Bing Chat, ChatGPT, intelligent Q&A from health apps like Dingxiang Yisheng. Suitable Uses: Popular science on common symptoms, lifestyle reminders, basic explanation of health metrics.

Example Prompts:

Suggestions for Children Assisting Parents:

  • Help elders add a “for informational purposes only, confirm with a doctor” reminder.
  • Require the AI to flag “uncertain/needs medical attention” situations.

Disclaimer: AI output does not replace professional medical diagnosis and prescription; for emergencies or medication, be sure to consult a doctor.

For Students: Homework Help and Writing Assistance

Section titled “For Students: Homework Help and Writing Assistance”

AI can solve problems, create outlines, explain concepts, and grade essays. But don’t just copy—teachers can easily recognize the writing style.

Recommended Tools: Bing (for photo-based problem solving/web search), ChatGPT (for step-by-step writing guidance), Photomath/Zuoyebang (for targeted problem solving). Suitable Uses: Step-by-step derivations, restating knowledge points, essay structure, oral/translation practice.

Example Prompts:

The Right Way to Use It:

  • Ask it to “give hints first, not the final answer directly.”
  • Have the AI grade your draft instead of writing the whole thing for you.
  • Ask it to point out “grammatical errors + reasons for improvement.”

Recommendation: Use it to learn “how to solve problems,” not to “learn for you.”

For General Entertainment Users: Image/Video/Audio Creativity

Section titled “For General Entertainment Users: Image/Video/Audio Creativity”

AI is a “low-barrier creation accelerator.” With precise prompt iteration, you can get results close to what you want.

Recommended Tools: Image: Midjourney / Stable Diffusion / DALL·E 3 Video: Runway / Gen-2 Audio: ElevenLabs / Azure TTS (Script ideas and combinations: ChatGPT)

Example Prompts:

Tips:

  • Structured prompts: Subject / Style / Lighting / Composition / Details / Quality.
  • Iterate repeatedly: Tell the model “the background in version 3 is too cluttered, please simplify it.”
  • Pay attention to copyright and portrait rights compliance.

Reminder: Before using AI-generated content for commercial purposes, verify copyright and licensing risks.

For Advanced Education: Structured Review / Self-Testing / Self-Study Partner

Section titled “For Advanced Education: Structured Review / Self-Testing / Self-Study Partner”

Use AI as an “active learning driver”: have it summarize, extract key points, create questions, grade, and role-play as a tutor.

Recommended Tools: ChatGPT (general + plugins), Bing (for real-time information), WolframAlpha (for mathematical rigor), GitHub Copilot (for programming), language apps (DuoLingo AI mode).

Example Prompts:

Effective Strategies:

  • Limit the output structure (e.g., “only give three levels of points, each no more than 12 words”).
  • Ask it to “list points you are unsure about or that might be incorrect.”
  • Use a “if I answer incorrectly, keep asking until I understand” loop for learning.

Pitfalls to Avoid:

  • When it conflicts with textbooks: ask for its source/possible reasons for conflict.
  • For formulas/data: demand “step-by-step derivation” to prevent hallucinations.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI is a “multi-scenario general enhancement tool”: it can empower conversation, analysis, popular science, creation, and learning. Core Principles:

  • Clearly define roles and tasks
  • Use structured prompts
  • Follow up and verify
  • It’s a tool, not an authority
  • Responsibility and decision-making are still yours

In what scenarios have you used AI? Feel free to share your interesting experiences. If you found this helpful, share it to help more people avoid pitfalls and be more efficient.

Universal Prompt Template Reference (Reusable)

Section titled “Universal Prompt Template Reference (Reusable)”

Disclaimer: The content in this article regarding investment and health is for informational purposes only and does not constitute investment, medical, legal, or professional advice; please consult authoritative channels and professionals.

Tags:
  • AI

Engineer Growth Principles in the AI Era

Sep 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

This article distills four often-overlooked yet crucial growth principles: argue less about who’s right and more for win–wins, ship first then optimize, don’t fear overlap—insist on differentiation, and stop wasting time proving yourself.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

As AI advances at breakneck speed, engineers face not only a technical upgrade but also a test of worldview and workplace mindset. Have you ever alienated a colleague by clinging to “being right”? Missed a window chasing perfection? These are common, and exactly what this piece explores. After years of trial and error, I’ve refined four practical growth principles that continue to work in the real world. I hope they resonate.

1. Incentive Thinking: Don’t Argue Right vs. Wrong—Argue for Win–Win

Section titled “1. Incentive Thinking: Don’t Argue Right vs. Wrong—Argue for Win–Win”

Early in my career, I was eager to prove I was “right.” Over time I realized: in organizations, “right” is rarely the most important thing—“what benefits the project/team” is. Obsessing over abstract “elegance” and “pure logic” while ignoring delivery, risk, resources, and ROI balance easily gets labeled as nitpicking.

Key mindset shifts:

  • From “I must win” to “Does the team get better overall?”
  • From “theoretical perfection” to “maximizing this iteration’s value”
  • From “debate positions” to “collaborative game → win–win options”

A practical trick: before speaking or rebutting, silently count to 5 and ask yourself:

  1. Will this statement move the decision or outcome forward?
  2. Is it fair and beneficial to both the other party and the team?
  3. Is there a way to express this with lower conflict cost?

Argue less about right/wrong, aim for win–wins, and your reputation as a collaborator—along with your influence and trust—will rise naturally.

2. No Premature Optimization: Ship First, Optimize After Validation

Section titled “2. No Premature Optimization: Ship First, Optimize After Validation”

Perfectionism often delays the first version. When users haven’t validated and value isn’t closed-loop, pouring effort into performance, abstraction, and grand architecture is classic “premature optimization.”

The first version (V0 / MVP) has only two missions:

  • Validate there are real users who want it.
  • Validate the path is worth doubling down on.

Practice tips:

  • Set your “Minimal Success Level” (MSL) for this round.
  • Cap initial delivery investment (person-days / complexity / dependencies).
  • Leave room for refactoring instead of hard-locking the architecture up-front.
  • Track hypothesis → ship → feedback → iteration cadence (accelerate loops, don’t just pile features).

When you see stable core usage + 100+ real, recurring users + paying signals or strong retention, that’s when systematic refactors/perf work actually pay off.

The mantra isn’t “settle for less,” it’s “validate fast + optimize with purpose.”

3. Don’t Be Intimidated by Logic: It’s Fine If Others Did It—Build Your Difference

Section titled “3. Don’t Be Intimidated by Logic: It’s Fine If Others Did It—Build Your Difference”

“Someone’s done it” isn’t a veto; it’s market proof and a learning sample. Differentiation isn’t only technical—often it comes from:

  • Perspective: a new framing, entry point, or audience focus for the same problem
  • Experience: compressed flows, friction removal, instant feedback
  • Value exchange: open/closed source, subscription/one-off, tool + community hybrids
  • Narrative and persona: trust and cultural tone as invisible moats

Suggested execution steps:

  1. List a pros/cons matrix of existing solutions.
  2. Highlight under-served user scenarios and emotional pain points.
  3. Define your “Differentiated Core” via subtraction: the smallest set that makes you distinct.
  4. Build a demo with perceivable differences first; collect real feedback, then expand.

Don’t overestimate the risk of “repetition” and underestimate the compounding of “consistency + differentiation + focus.”

4. Stop Proving Yourself: Spend Energy on Building and Joy

Section titled “4. Stop Proving Yourself: Spend Energy on Building and Joy”

For technologists, the scarcest resource isn’t tools—it’s sustained, deep attention. Instead of bleeding energy in pointless debates and emotional tug-of-war, convert your will to win into building power.

Common self-draining traps:

  • “I must make them admit I know more.”
  • “Their lack of recognition = I’m not good.”
  • “I must clap back at every jab.”

Replacements:

  • Let outcomes/code/metrics/demos speak.
  • Identify “non-productive debates”: not falsifiable + no decision rights + emotion-led.
  • Maintain a personal “attention blacklist”: don’t trigger, don’t chase, don’t loop.
  • Build positive loops: output (articles/open source/prototypes) → feedback → improvement.

Let your work establish your identity and reputation—not momentary keyboard wins.

Final Thoughts

Section titled “Final Thoughts”

To recap the four principles:

  1. Argue less about right/wrong; aim for win–wins.
  2. Validate value first; then refine and optimize.
  3. Don’t fear overlap; insist on differentiation.
  4. Don’t waste energy proving; commit to sustained creation.

In the AI era, tool dividends are accelerating “capability depreciation.” Knowing a stack is no longer a lasting moat. What compounds sustainably is:

  • Mindset flexibility
  • Strategic execution
  • Differentiated expression
  • Focus and continuous retrospection

The path of growth is inevitably winding. If your direction is right, the distance won’t matter. May we embrace the technological tide while consolidating inner judgment and creativity.

Tags:
  • AI

2025 U.S. Valuation Logic: AI, Nuclear, Quantum, Rare Earths — What’s Real and What’s Hype?

Sep 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Retail investors may have noticed recently that shares of several U.S.-listed companies involved in frontier technologies have surged. This report analyzes their core businesses, the drivers behind the rallies, the degree of disconnect between valuation and fundamentals, the sustainability of their business models, industry trends and market sentiment, and each company’s moat and competitiveness—so you can better understand the logic, risks, and opportunities behind lofty valuations.

Overview of the Surging Names

Section titled “Overview of the Surging Names”

The table below summarizes several stocks that have recently posted outsized gains, their positioning, approximate performance, and the main drivers:

Company (Ticker)PositioningRecent Performance (approx.)Key Drivers
Opendoor (OPEN)PropTech (home-trading platform)+1500% (since early July)Founders returned; new CEO appointed; became a retail-fueled meme stock
Iris Energy (IREN)HPC / Data centers (AI compute)+250% (early 2023 to June 2023)Pivot from Bitcoin mining to AI infrastructure; expanding green data centers; Nvidia partnership
Nebius (NBIS)AI infrastructure cloud services+>500% (YTD)Won a Microsoft AI compute contract up to $17.4B; surging AI compute demand; Nvidia support
Oklo (OKLO)Micro‑nuclear (SMRs)+600% (past year)U.S. Air Force base micro‑nuclear contract; regulatory progress; backed by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman
D‑Wave (QBTS)Quantum computing (quantum annealing)+1480% (past year)Momentum in quantum computing theme; small but fast‑growing revenue (H1 revenue ~$18M); peer re‑rating (e.g., IonQ)
IonQ (IONQ)Quantum computing (trapped‑ion)+652% (past year)Leading hardware approach with active M&A; quantum seen as the “next tech revolution”
MP Materials (MP)Rare earths (permanent magnets)+75% (past year, est.)Halted exports to China with U.S. support; rare‑earth prices up ~40% to two‑year highs; DoD invested ~$400M
Robinhood (HOOD)Fintech (zero‑commission broker)+1600% (off lows)Higher rates boosted interest income; revenue +58% YoY, swing to profit; regained retail momentum; added to S&P 500
Rocket Lab (RKLB)Launch + satellite services+1000% (since 2023)Commercial order boom (Q4 revenue +121% YoY); first Neutron contract; backlog >$1B
Pony.ai (PONY)Autonomous driving (robotaxi)+500% (since IPO, ~1 year)Robotaxi commercialization accelerating (300‑vehicle fleet; Q1 revenue ~$14M); partnerships (e.g., Uber); index inclusion; ARK interest

Note: The performance figures above are rough estimates; please refer to actual market data for precise pricing.

Next, we analyze each company in detail.

OPEN – Opendoor Technologies (PropTech)

Section titled “OPEN – Opendoor Technologies (PropTech)”
  1. Core Business and Industry Positioning

Opendoor is a technology-driven real estate transaction platform that pioneered the home “instant buy-sell” (iBuyer) model. The company uses algorithms to value homes, buys directly and resells quickly, earning a spread and service fees. Opendoor was once the largest iBuyer in the U.S. and a leader in proptech.

However, the model is highly sensitive to home-price volatility. The U.S. housing downturn in 2022 led to heavy losses for Opendoor, while peers like Zillow withdrew from iBuying. Despite setbacks, Opendoor’s first-mover advantage and data trove still make it a pioneer in digitized home transactions.

  1. Share-Price Drivers

In H2 2025, Opendoor staged a short-squeeze-style surge, up more than 15x from early July to mid‑September. This was driven by both fundamental/management changes and sentiment.

In September, cofounders Keith Rabois and Eric Wu returned to the board as chair and director, respectively—leaders of Opendoor’s early hyper‑growth. The new CEO is former Shopify executive Kaz Nejatian, expected to bring commerce DNA.

These leadership moves were read as a turnaround signal and cheered by investors, especially retail communities. Hedge fund manager Eric Jackson openly backed the founders’ return, helping turn Opendoor into a 2025 meme stock.

Macro expectations also improved—hopes that Fed hikes were nearing an end and mortgage rates had peaked—fueling optimism about a housing rebound and Opendoor’s recovery. Retail buying and short covering compounded the rally.

  1. Valuation Froth vs. Fundamentals

Opendoor’s price is far above what current fundamentals support, with clear froth. While leadership changes boosted confidence, the core business did not improve overnight. The company is still digesting inventory losses from prior high‑price purchases and has not restored profitability.

Year‑to‑date the stock jumped over 476% (as of mid‑September) without commensurate revenue or profit growth—pricing in hopes of a turnaround rather than current performance. Retail forums frequently compare it to past meme stocks like GameStop. If fundamentals fail to deliver, downside is material.

  1. Business Model Sustainability

Opendoor’s iBuyer model essentially acts as a housing “market maker,” using its own balance sheet to absorb price risk in exchange for convenience. Sustainability depends on accurate pricing and effective inventory management.

History shows the model works in one‑way up markets but can incur severe losses when conditions reverse. Opendoor is refining models, shortening hold times, and partnering with traditional agents to reduce risk.

Durability hinges on risk control and the housing backdrop. A stable/warmer market could restore positive gross margins and profits; sharp price swings or recessionary demand could again expose fragility. Opendoor has ample cash to buffer near‑term volatility, and the founders’ return may drive a lighter‑asset tilt. The model is disruptive but its sustainable profitability still needs proof.

  1. Industry Trend, Valuation, and Attention

Online home transactions keep rising, but iBuying—the most aggressive sub‑model—has seen divergence: Zillow exited after big losses, and Redfin shrank exposure. Opendoor is now almost a lone player, with some “first‑mover premium.” After a weak 2022–23, proptech regained attention in 2025, with Opendoor the poster child.

Versus traditional agents, tech names like Opendoor command higher multiples; recent gains pushed valuation to extremes (e.g., sales multiples far above peers). Social‑media‑coordinated retail flows plus some institutional follow‑through spiked volumes. Such hot attention can be fleeting; if narratives fade or results disappoint, flows reverse quickly. Expect high volatility at elevated multiples.

  1. Moat and Competitiveness

Advantages include data‑/algorithm‑driven pricing, national operating scale, and first‑mover brand recognition. Years of transaction data deepen the AVM, and the one‑stop fast‑close experience is compelling.

But this is not an impregnable moat: large portals or financials could build similar platforms; barriers are not high, and success requires carrying inventory and capital costs many players do not want. The main “competitor” remains the traditional brokerage route, especially in soft markets where sellers prefer listing over discounting. Opendoor’s strength is bold model innovation—but the moat remains unproven. Much of the recent rally is meme/sentiment rather than sudden fundamental outperformance; robust execution is required to sustain value.

IREN – Iris Energy (High‑Performance Computing / Data Centers)

Section titled “IREN – Iris Energy (High‑Performance Computing / Data Centers)”
  1. Core Business and Industry Positioning

Australia‑born Iris Energy started as a low‑cost, renewable‑powered Bitcoin miner. Since 2023 it has pivoted to broader HPC, especially AI compute, leveraging its strength in large‑scale infrastructure.

Iris has built large campuses in Canada and elsewhere, with >5.6 EH/s Bitcoin hash rate and hundreds of megawatts of power capacity, part of which can be repurposed for AI training. In early 2024 it rebranded to “IREN” to reflect a focus beyond crypto into full‑stack AI infrastructure.

In the “Bitcoin mining + AI compute” overlap, IREN is an early mover, collaborating with Nvidia, Dell, and others on HPC solutions. As more miners attempt AI pivots, IREN aims to solidify first‑mover advantages and a durable foothold in high‑performance data centers.

  1. Share-Price Drivers

The stock climbed >250% from early to mid‑2023, then surged multiple times in 2024–2025 alongside AI. For instance, in September 2025 it spiked ~15% on heavy volume as investors extrapolated Nebius–Microsoft contract news to IREN’s AI infrastructure potential.

The company announced plans to deploy 9,000 GPUs with Nvidia to expand HPC, and August bitcoin revenue rose to ~$79M—reinforcing confidence it can capture AI compute upside. FY2023 revenue grew >280% YoY, indicating the pivot is taking hold. With retail buzz strong, the AI compute narrative is the core driver, amplified by marquee partners and macro tailwinds.

  1. Valuation Froth vs. Fundamentals

With the rally, IREN’s valuation rerated far above typical mining comps and even above traditional data‑center peers, as markets recast it as an AI infrastructure play. Yet the company remains relatively small—1H25 revenue was only in the tens of millions, and post‑pivot profitability is unproven. Price appreciation has outpaced near‑term revenue growth, suggesting sentiment heat. Low bases can justify high growth rates early, but delivery is key. If revenue doubles into 2026 as some expect, current multiples could be defensible; if AI demand underwhelms or competition compresses margins, the stock could give back gains. Speculation is present; watch for delivery risk.

  1. Business Model Sustainability

IREN is shifting from volatile crypto mining to steadier compute‑as‑a‑service. Sustainability hinges on renting capacity to AI/cloud customers for recurring revenue. Advantages include cheap clean power and existing infrastructure—core to competitive compute economics—plus compatibility with mainstream AI hardware via Nvidia partnerships. But balancing mining and HPC is crucial: crypto still contributes the majority of revenue, and crypto cycles remain unreliable to support a high valuation. IREN must keep winning non‑crypto customers and large contracts. Capex demands are heavy (data centers, tens of thousands of GPUs), so financing and profitability pressures loom. Cash of ~$146M (early‑2024) and low debt help near term. If AI demand persists and execution is strong, the model can be sustainably profitable; if bitcoin halving cuts mining income and AI ramps lag, both legs could wobble. The litmus test is whether it can truly become a “compute landlord” versus a miner.

  1. Industry Trend, Valuation, and Attention

GenAI has triggered a global GPU land‑grab since 2023; data centers entered a boom cycle. Forecasts put AI‑related DC spend at ~$76B by 2028. Sector valuations are elevated (e.g., Nvidia), and small/mid AI infra names draw hot money. IREN’s volume spikes on contract headlines. But competition is rising: North American miners (e.g., Hut 8) and traditional colos are entering HPC. Expect dispersion and normalized multiples as the field crowds. Attention and valuation ride on the AI upcycle; any cooling (lower AI capex, signs of overcapacity) could reverse sentiment.

  1. Moat and Competitive Advantages

Low‑cost, green, large‑scale infrastructure is IREN’s edge, honed by years of remote‑site operations with low electricity cost and high efficiency. A 3.1‑GW expansion plan underscores scale. Nvidia alignment improves access to advanced GPUs during shortages. The moat is resource/operations‑driven rather than software/ecosystem; compute is relatively commoditized, and cloud hyperscalers or colos are formidable competitors. Differentiation must come from service quality, latency/location advantages, and customer relationships. Some of the rally is “AI tailwind,” not proprietary tech; building durable moats requires more than the theme.

3. NBIS – Nebius Group NV (AI Infrastructure Cloud Services)

Section titled “3. NBIS – Nebius Group NV (AI Infrastructure Cloud Services)”
  1. Core Business and Industry Positioning

Nebius is a Netherlands‑based AI infrastructure provider offering a full stack of GPU cloud, developer tools, and AI solutions—building and operating large GPU clusters and cloud architecture for training/inference. Business lines include the AI cloud platform, autonomous‑driving development services, and the Toloka crowdsourcing data platform. Spun out of Yandex’s overseas unit in 2022, Nebius is led by Yandex founder Arkady Volozh (CEO), inheriting Yandex’s cloud/AI expertise. Nvidia is a key partner/investor, and Nebius brands itself as “Nvidia‑backed.” Positioning as a neutral AI compute provider in Europe and emerging markets, it competes for high‑end GPU cloud with Oracle Cloud, Lambda Labs, etc. Backed by deep capital and Yandex DNA, Nebius is scaling fast and drawing market attention.

  1. Share-Price Drivers

Since its late‑2023 SPAC listing, the stock climbed from ~$14 to >$100 within 52 weeks (>6x). In Sept 2025 Nebius announced a five‑year AI infrastructure contract with Microsoft worth up to $17.4B, sending shares up ~47% after hours and ~50% the next day on surging volume. Microsoft will lease substantial GPU capacity from Nebius’s new New Jersey facility to expand Azure. The deal validates Nebius’s model and capacity to win top‑tier customers. Management suggests more large contracts are in the pipeline. Earlier, Jeff Bezos led a funding round into Toloka; Russian billionaire Potanin invested into the Yandex successor structure. The immediate catalyst is the Microsoft mega‑deal; the ongoing story is Nebius as a scarce “AI infra mini‑giant.”

  1. Valuation Froth vs. Fundamentals

Nebius’s market cap exceeds $20B despite limited historical revenue (Q1 2025 revenue was ~ $14M). Even assuming multi‑billion annual contract inflows, the stock already prices very aggressive growth.
