Refer to the official site for the latest; preview details may change.

How do credits burn?
Features like Chat, Agent, Quest bill by model price × tokens; failed requests do not burn credits; when monthly allocation is exhausted, the system may fall back to a base model and reset next month.

Industry context: Cursor uses a hybrid of “subscription + request/agent usage limits”, and Claude Code follows a membership + add‑on route. In short, AI IDE membership loops have solidified, which explains why competitors converge on this model.

Recommended Use Cases (Product/Backend/Frontend/DevOps)

Section titled “Recommended Use Cases (Product/Backend/Frontend/DevOps)”

A. One‑shot delivery: spec → implement → verify
Example: add “multi‑tenant billing” to an existing service. Hand the requirement to Quest Mode to draft a spec, then implement and produce a regression report.

B. Ramp up on a legacy repo
Open the repo, let Repo Wiki initialize, then ask “how does order flow work?” or “which module depends on A/B/C?”.

C. Large‑scale refactors/framework swaps
Encode code style and docs via Rules, then let the Agent apply changes in bulk; use NES to land edits incrementally.

D. Cross‑language migration / unit test backfill
Scope with @folder + @gitCommit, have the agent identify critical paths, backfill tests, and generate a diff report.

E. Integrate third‑party/private systems
Use MCP to connect internal APIs, databases, and scripts to automate “query/write‑back/batch ops”.

F. Team collaboration and knowledge capture
Leverage Repo Wiki + Memory for shared knowledge; keep Rules in‑repo so they travel with code, enabling newcomers to ship in week one.

My 30‑Minute Onboarding Script

Section titled “My 30‑Minute Onboarding Script”
  1. Install and sign in (5 min).
  2. Configure proxy if needed (3 min).
  3. Open your business repo and let Repo Wiki initialize (runs in background).
  4. Write three hard Rules for “project comments / commit messages / testing requirements”.
  5. Start a Quest for a small, well‑scoped feature; review the Spec, add edge cases and acceptance criteria as needed.
  6. Watch the Action Flow, add requirements mid‑run to see how it re‑plans.
  7. Based on the Task Report, Accept/Discard and use NES for quick tweaks.

Takeaways

Section titled “Takeaways”
  • Qoder’s value: a jump from completion to delivery — there’s a spec, a plan, and a receipt.
  • Experience hinges on: Repo Wiki’s architecture‑level context, Rules’ governance, and MCP’s extensibility.
  • Business model: membership + credits is becoming standard; Qoder’s “preview‑free + Pro trial + extra credit packs” makes switching costs friendly.

Questions to Ponder

Section titled “Questions to Ponder”
  • Which repetitive changes will you entrust to Quest?
  • What three team conventions should be codified as Rules first?
  • If you wire up MCP, which internal system do you want agents to touch first?
Tags:
  • AI
  • Software Engineering

Google Gemini: A Complete AI Educational System - Teachers Assign AI Experts, Students Create Custom Quizzes, Privacy and Compliance

Aug 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

This isn’t “another chatbot.” This is a system-level upgrade that packages learning processes, classroom management, content production, assessment feedback, and privacy compliance all in one.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

After this year’s ISTE conference, Google has turned Gemini for Education into school-level AI infrastructure: Educational Gemini (based on 2.5 Pro) is freely available with Workspace for Education, connecting all key actions for teachers, students, and administrators.

What’s more impressive is that teachers can create and assign “Gems (AI experts)”, NotebookLM generates video overviews as micro-lessons with one click, Forms includes Gemini auto-generated questions, and Vids uses Veo 3 to generate 8-second videos with sound effects. Students use Canvas for personalized quizzes, with answers including interactive charts to aid understanding. Administrators can search all Gemini conversations in Vault, view usage reports, and maintain compliance trails.

The most crucial point: In educational contexts, chat data is not used for model training (enterprise-level data protection).

I. System Overview: A New Paradigm for Education × AI

Section titled “I. System Overview: A New Paradigm for Education × AI”
  • Gemini for Education: Based on Gemini 2.5 Pro, defaults to high-tier models with admin control, included free with Workspace for Education.
  • Gemini in Classroom: Free for all education editions, 30+ new AI capabilities for lesson planning, differentiated instruction, vocabulary lists, etc.
  • Teacher-led AI: Teachers directly assign Gems and NotebookLM notebooks to students (Classroom & LTI integration with Canvas/Schoology).
  • NotebookLM Video Overviews: One-click generation of explanatory videos and key points from materials.
  • Veo 3 in Vids: 8-second short videos with native sound effects/narration, suitable for experiment demonstrations and course previews.
  • Gemini Forms: One-click quiz/survey generation from Docs/Slides/PDFs, with AI-summarized responses.
  • Gemini Canvas Quizzes: 18+ students can generate personalized practice, with positive extension to minors.
  • Privacy and Compliance: Common Sense Privacy Seal, Vault searchable conversations, admin-configurable retention policies and reports.

II. How Teachers Use It: Lesson Planning Efficiency × Differentiated Instruction

Section titled “II. How Teachers Use It: Lesson Planning Efficiency × Differentiated Instruction”

High-Frequency Usage Checklist

  1. 5-Minute “Tiered Classroom” Scripts

    • Have Gemini generate “same topic, different depths” lesson plans and exercises based on three proficiency levels in the same class; automatically includes example sentences and visual cues.

  2. Create “Interactive Simulation” Gems (AI Experts)

    • Upload this week’s assignments + reading materials to generate interactive experts for follow-up questions; assign to students for preview before class and reinforcement after. Shareable with teaching teams.

  3. NotebookLM → “Video Overview” Micro-lessons

    • Generate 1-3 minute videos from syllabi/lecture notes with one click, suitable for flipped classrooms and makeup lessons for absent students.

  4. Forms One-Click Questions + AI Grading Summaries

    • Use “help me create a form” to generate quizzes from Docs/Slides/PDFs; automatically summarize key points and weak areas after submission.

  5. Vids × Veo 3 Demo Short Videos

    • 8-second “experiment/phenomenon” demonstration openings with sound effects; engaging and time-saving.

III. How Students Learn: Adaptive Practice × Visual Understanding

Section titled “III. How Students Learn: Adaptive Practice × Visual Understanding”
  • Gemini Canvas Personalized Quizzes: Input review scope, system generates questions based on weak areas with progressive feedback.
  • Interactive Charts/Diagrams: Gemini responses include interactive visualizations to help clarify complex concepts and multi-step reasoning.
  • Receive Classroom Gems and NotebookLM: Access teacher-assigned “AI experts” and resource notebooks in real-time, asking questions while learning.

Self-Study Prompt Examples (Ready to Copy)

  • “Based on my error log, generate 15 mixed-difficulty test questions, give one hint per question, don’t provide direct answers.”
  • “Use three diagrams to explain ‘entropy increase’: intuition, key formula derivation steps, and real-world analogies.”

IV. Administrator Perspective: Compliance, Visibility, Control

Section titled “IV. Administrator Perspective: Compliance, Visibility, Control”
  • Permissions and Age Tiers: Control who can use Gemini/NotebookLM, configurable 18+ feature differences.
  • Vault eDiscovery: Search Gemini conversations by domain, export for legal retention; Workspace updates already cover education editions.
  • Usage Reports and Retention Policies: View who’s using what and how much, set chat preservation and auto-deletion cycles.
  • Privacy Endorsements: Common Sense Privacy Seal, educational account chats not used for model training, no human review.

Additional option: Enable Temporary Chats (temporary conversations), not counted toward personalization and training, short-term retention.

V. Implementation Framework: One Class from 0 to 1

Section titled “V. Implementation Framework: One Class from 0 to 1”

Goal: 60-minute “Electromagnetic Induction” lesson

  1. Pre-class: Teacher uses NotebookLM to generate “video overview” + vocabulary list; Vids uses Veo 3 for 8-second intro clip.
  2. In-class: Assign “Interactive Simulation” Gem, groups explore “Faraday’s experiment” variable effects; Gemini responses embed interactive diagrams.
  3. Assessment: Forms auto-generates in-class quiz, Gemini summarizes class weak points after lesson ends.
  4. Post-class: Students use Canvas to generate personalized quizzes, re-practice based on errors.
  5. Management: Administrator maintains trails in Vault and exports sample conversations for compliance.

VI. Boundaries and Risks: Don’t Turn AI into an “Answer Vending Machine”

Section titled “VI. Boundaries and Risks: Don’t Turn AI into an “Answer Vending Machine””
  • Academic Integrity: Recommend using AI for “inspiration and structuring,” avoid directly producing plagiarizable final drafts.
  • Data Minimization: Educational accounts default to “not used for training,” still recommend avoiding uploading sensitive identity information.
  • Capability and Dependency: AI excels at “raising the floor,” focus on developing self-explanation and multi-step reasoning abilities to prevent over-reliance.
  • Traceability: During important exam periods, combine Vault spot-checks with usage reports to form school-specific “AI usage guidelines.”

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Google has transformed “AI + Education” from tool-level integration into a system-level paradigm. Teachers have “AI colleagues,” students have “AI study companions,” administrators have “AI compliance dashboards.” Content, processes, privacy, and governance form a complete closed loop across four dimensions.

The first step you can take now: Choose a lesson you’ll teach next week and run through the “0 to 1” framework above. You’ll discover that AI isn’t just “helping you,” it’s “reorganizing the classroom.” What do you think?

Tags:
  • AI
  • Google Gemini
  • Education

Why AI Product Development Differs from Traditional Software: Continuous Calibration and Continuous Development — Uncertainty and the ‘Agency vs. Control’ Challenge

Aug 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

The current wave of generative AI has pushed companies to ship AI‑powered features for fear of missing the moment. ByteDance launched the conversational app “Doubao,” and Tencent rolled out its in‑house chat assistant “Yuanbao.” Many product teams, under executive pressure, rapidly integrated AI: the idea looked promising, the demo dazzled, and early user feedback seemed positive. Yet once the product goes live, reality bites. The system surfaces unexpected errors; users bring a wild variety of requests; AI responses are inconsistent. Teams dig in and find the issues are intertwined and hard to attribute to a single fix, shaking confidence in the entire product approach. Worse, these hidden faults quietly erode user trust.

Why the yawning gap between a slick demo and a fragile production reality? At the root, AI products break several assumptions that traditional software depends on. If you build AI products the traditional way, you’ll hit trap after trap. Boiled down, there are two critical differences to take seriously:

  • AI products are inherently uncertain — both user inputs and model outputs are unpredictable.
  • AI products must balance agency and control — every time you grant the system more autonomous “agency,” you cede some human control. Ignore this and push autonomy too far, and you invite runaway decisions and hard‑to‑trace errors.

Many teams miss these two differences, leading to cascading problems during scale‑up and optimization: bizarre failures, bad decisions, even trust crises. To address these challenges, experienced practitioners have proposed a new product development frame that helps teams build stable, trustworthy AI features with intent. Below we unpack the two differences and introduce the Continuous Calibration / Continuous Development (CC/CD) loop that tackles them, followed by a concrete example showing how to ship AI features step by step in daily work.

The Uncertainty of AI Products

Section titled “The Uncertainty of AI Products”

Traditional software tends to be deterministic. User interactions are limited and explicit: clicking buttons, filling forms, calling fixed APIs. Developers hard‑code logic to map inputs to outputs. When something breaks, it’s usually a code bug that’s relatively easy to locate and fix.

AI products are born uncertain. They introduce a double layer of unpredictability:

  1. Input uncertainty

    • Inputs are no longer constrained to predefined operations; they may be open‑ended natural language, voice commands, images, and more.
    • Expressions are flexible, hard to exhaustively validate, and prone to ambiguity.
    • In support bots, the same question can be phrased in hundreds of ways; in content generation, prompt nuances produce drastically different results; in code assistants, vague requirements can yield entirely different implementations.

  2. Output uncertainty

    • Traditional software produces the same output for the same input; AI models generate probabilistic answers — essentially, “best guesses.”
    • The same request can vary across contexts, times, or model versions.
    • Output uncertainty makes testing harder — classic unit tests don’t fit; you need to assess quality by probabilities and trends.

Therefore, AI product development must accept: model behavior is not absolutely controllable; you must continuously observe and calibrate deviations from intent.

Balancing Agency and Control

Section titled “Balancing Agency and Control”

Another defining difference is the introduction of “agency” — the system’s ability to act and decide on the user’s behalf.

  • High‑agency examples

    • A support bot replies directly to users
    • A writing assistant auto‑publishes articles
    • A code assistant commits changes to a repo

  • Risks and issues

    • More autonomy → weaker control
    • When wrong, consequences exceed typical bugs
    • Harder to trace root causes; debugging and fixes get tougher

So autonomy must be “earned” gradually:

  • Start with assistive suggestions (low agency, high control) and human review
  • Increase permissions after proven reliability
  • Keep human takeover and rollback paths

This stepwise approach avoids large losses from AI mistakes and steadily builds user trust.

The CC/CD Framework

Section titled “The CC/CD Framework”

The CC/CD framework borrows from CI/CD but targets AI’s uncertainty and staged empowerment. It alternates Continuous Development (CD) with Continuous Calibration (CC).

Continuous Development (CD)

Section titled “Continuous Development (CD)”
  • Define capability scope; plan staged version boundaries
  • Build an app prototype; add logging and human‑fallbacks
  • Design evaluation metrics (Evals) to set baselines for calibration
  • Roll out to a small cohort and start gathering real feedback

Continuous Calibration (CC)

Section titled “Continuous Calibration (CC)”
  • Run evaluations to verify real‑world performance
  • Analyze logs to locate error patterns
  • Targeted improvements to prompts, retrieval, models, or data
  • Iterate until behavior stabilizes and becomes trustworthy

As loops progress, capabilities rise and agency expands — while safety and trust stay intact.

Case Study: Building a Support Bot in Stages

Section titled “Case Study: Building a Support Bot in Stages”

Version 1: AI‑assisted ticket routing (low agency, high control)

Section titled “Version 1: AI‑assisted ticket routing (low agency, high control)”
  • Role: classify only → route to the right team
  • Metric: routing accuracy
  • Low risk; humans can correct anytime
  • After calibration, accuracy can exceed 95%

Version 2: AI‑suggested replies (medium agency, medium control)

Section titled “Version 2: AI‑suggested replies (medium agency, medium control)”
  • Role: draft responses → humans review and send
  • Metrics: adoption rate and consistency
  • Improve retrieval to boost specificity and expertise
  • Draft adoption rises from 50% to 80%

Version 3: AI resolves issues autonomously (high agency, low control)

Section titled “Version 3: AI resolves issues autonomously (high agency, low control)”
  • Role: direct replies → restricted to high‑frequency, low‑risk scenarios
  • Metrics: auto‑resolution rate and CSAT
  • Start narrow, then expand coverage gradually
  • Keep human takeover and post‑hoc sampling in place

Through these three stages, the bot evolves from “assistive” to “self‑service,” lifting efficiency while preserving reliability.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Building AI products is like welcoming a brilliant but new teammate:

  • Don’t grant full autonomy on day one — let them learn the business step by step
  • Give room while keeping oversight to ensure correct direction
  • Continuous calibration with gradual empowerment is the only stable path

The core of CC/CD:

  • Facing uncertainty → observe and calibrate continuously
  • Facing autonomy → grant agency stepwise, evolve as needed

This way, AI becomes a reliable “team member,” upgrading experience and efficiency while protecting trust.

Tags:
  • AI
  • Team Management

OpenAI $500B Valuation vs. Palantir: Bubble Analysis Report

Aug 20, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Deep‑dive based on Citron Research’s Palantir note, cross‑checked with public sources. We examine AI equity froth, test the report’s claims, and outline key risks for Palantir’s path ahead.

Key takeaways

Section titled “Key takeaways”

Headline comparison argument

Section titled “Headline comparison argument”

Citron frames a stark P/S comparison: OpenAI at a $500B valuation against a 2026 revenue estimate of $29.6B implies ~17× P/S; Palantir at $5.6B 2026 revenue on 17× P/S implies ~$40/share — far below the then‑market price near ~$170.

Claimed datapoints

Section titled “Claimed datapoints”
  1. OpenAI staff selling ~$6B secondary at ~$500B valuation.
  2. Sam Altman publicly acknowledges an AI bubble risk.
  3. Alex Karp has sold nearly ~$2B of Palantir stock over two years.
  4. Palantir’s revenue is “lumpy,” dependent on government contracts.
  5. Forward Deployed Engineers (FDE) model is costly with negative marginal profits in many cases.

Fact‑checks and validation

Section titled “Fact‑checks and validation”

OpenAI valuation and “bubble” remarks — accurate

Section titled “OpenAI valuation and “bubble” remarks — accurate”

Multiple outlets confirm a ~$6B employee tender at a ~$500B valuation. In Aug‑2025, Sam Altman stated investors are “over‑excited” about AI, likening conditions to the dot‑com era.

Palantir financials — broadly correct

Section titled “Palantir financials — broadly correct”
  • 2026 revenue ~$5.6B: Bloomberg consensus within range.
  • Valuation multiples: at ~$170/share, P/S in the 60–70× zone.
  • Mix: government ~55% of revenue; U.S. gov revenue +53% YoY in 2Q25.

Insider selling — understated in report

Section titled “Insider selling — understated in report”

Karp sold ~$1.88B in 2024 (about ~$1.4B clustered around the U.S. election). Other insiders including Peter Thiel sold >$4B in 2024.

FDE cost structure — corroborated

Section titled “FDE cost structure — corroborated”

A former engineer describes FDE as hiring top talent at very high cost; “in many cases marginal profit is effectively negative because we ‘give away’ projects.”

Logical gaps and limitations

Section titled “Logical gaps and limitations”

1) P/S comparability is weak

Section titled “1) P/S comparability is weak”

OpenAI’s consumer/SaaS flywheel differs fundamentally from Palantir’s gov‑heavy, high‑touch enterprise delivery. Risk, predictability, and scalability profiles diverge, limiting simple multiple transfer.

2) Selective emphasis on growth stability

Section titled “2) Selective emphasis on growth stability”

The note underplays U.S. commercial momentum: Palantir’s U.S. commercial revenue grew +93% YoY in 2Q25. Total revenue +48% with Rule‑of‑40 ~94 — strong growth/profit balance.

3) Competitive threat overstated

Section titled “3) Competitive threat overstated”

Databricks is often a partner, not just a rival. In Apr‑2025 they announced a collaboration; practitioners report coexistence targeting different use‑cases within the same orgs.

Motives and incentives

Section titled “Motives and incentives”

Citron’s posture and track record

Section titled “Citron’s posture and track record”

Andrew Left resumed public criticism after saying he’d step back post‑GME. He now faces 19 criminal counts tied to alleged market manipulation. WSJ tallied 111 Citron reports (2001‑2014): 90 stocks fell a year later, avg −42% — headline “hit rate” ~81% (methodology caveats apply).

Incentive‑driven readings

Section titled “Incentive‑driven readings”

Karp’s sales can reflect: (1) liquidity diversification post‑IPO; (2) tax planning via 10b5‑1; (3) mixed signals as he also exercises options. Meanwhile, ARK and other institutions increased exposure, calling Palantir “critical AI infrastructure.”

Palantir: past, present, forward

Section titled “Palantir: past, present, forward”

Performance recap (2020–2025)

Section titled “Performance recap (2020–2025)”
  • 2020: DPO at $23.55 amidst early enthusiasm.
  • 2021–2022: tech bear market; trough near ~$6.
  • 2023: AI narrative rebound to ~$17.17.
  • 2024: AI + U.S. election momentum; +340% to ~$75.63.
  • 2025: peaked near ~$190; pulled back to ~$157.

Current fundamentals

Section titled “Current fundamentals”

Strengths:

  1. GAAP profitable for 8 straight quarters; 46% adj. op margin.
  2. Durable gov contracts; $10B U.S. DoD award underpins LT visibility.
  3. U.S. commercial inflection: revenue +93% YoY; customers +43%.

Risks:

  1. Valuation stretched: P/E > 490×; rich vs peers.
  2. Customer concentration: top‑3 ~17% of revenue.
  3. Intl commercial softness: −3% YoY.

Forward growth scenarios

Section titled “Forward growth scenarios”

Bull:

  • Street: 2025–2027 revenue CAGR ~25.3%, net income CAGR ~31.6%.
  • AIP drives enterprise AI adoption.

Bear:

  • Gov budget headwinds.
  • AI commoditization undermines bespoke services.
  • High‑touch cost structure limits scale economics.

Valuation sanity check

Section titled “Valuation sanity check”

Peers and positioning

Section titled “Peers and positioning”

At ~$373B mkt cap and ~$28.7B TTM revenue, P/S ~13× — high for SaaS, but backed by:

  1. Quality of growth: +48% revenue, Rule‑of‑40 ~94.
  2. Defensive mix: sticky gov customers, high switching costs.
  3. AI first‑mover: enterprise deployment moat forming.

Range view (DCF + comps)

Section titled “Range view (DCF + comps)”
  • Conservative: $80–120 (slower growth, multiple compression)
  • Base case: $120–180 (trend sustained)
  • Optimistic: $180–250 (broad commercial breakout)

At ~$157, shares sit near the low end of “base case,” with downside risk if growth cools.

Conclusion and strategy

Section titled “Conclusion and strategy”

Judgments:

  1. Citron’s critique has signal: valuation is elevated; the $40 target is extreme but flags a fundamentals‑price gap.
  2. Inflection risk: success in shifting mix from gov‑centric to scalable commercial will determine LT value.
  3. AI froth: Altman’s warning is credible; sector‑wide multiple risk remains.

Positioning:

  • 6–12 months: hold cautiously; watch 3Q/4Q cadence in U.S. commercial.
  • 1–3 years: track logo retention, intl expansion, and cost discipline.
  • 3–5 years: platform economics could unlock further upside if scale achieved.

Risk control: size ≤5% of portfolio; consider stop near ~$120.

Palantir exemplifies the new AI‑era enterprise stack, but today’s price likely discounts 3–5 years of growth. Recognize LT potential while preparing for ST volatility.

Note: For research only, not investment advice.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • Palantir
  • NYSE: PLTR
  • AI
  • US Stock Market

Adapt Team Management to the AI Era: Turn Personal ‘Amplifiers’ into Team Defaults

Aug 19, 2025
Vibe Sparking

AI is a personal amplifier. First, use AI to make one “lead operator” self‑sustaining; don’t worship big‑tech resumes; be careful with KPI/OKR idolatry; practice self‑discipline to enable others; and remember there is no shortcut. This piece turns those principles into executable team practices.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

AI isn’t just another tool — it multiplies individual firepower. Those who wield it can be “1 person doing the work of 10”; those who don’t may not even notice the gap widening. Empirical studies show significant productivity gains in writing tasks, and customer support improves by ~14% on average, with larger gains for less experienced workers.

Implication: shift management focus from “policing process and headcount” to “managing leverage and cadence.”

Eight hard rules to change now

Section titled “Eight hard rules to change now”

1) Make the “AI amplifier” a default setting

Section titled “1) Make the “AI amplifier” a default setting”

Set a clear goal: 90% of routine actions have an AI variant. From SOPs, dailies, weekly notes to code reviews and requirement breakdowns — always provide a with‑AI path. Reason: McKinsey estimates $2.6–$4.4T of annual value from gen‑AI, compounding labor productivity over time.

2) Build an “AI lead goose,” then replicate

Section titled “2) Build an “AI lead goose,” then replicate”

Don’t train everyone first. Start with 1–3 lead operators who can run a business slice on AI:

  • A growth thread: lead cleaning, DM automation, landing‑page A/B.
  • A delivery thread: code+tests generation, doc automation, customer reply drafts. Scale by “demonstrate → follow” to the second wave. Real projects align expectations and shape culture.

3) Evolve performance from “output volume” to “AI leverage”

Section titled “3) Evolve performance from “output volume” to “AI leverage””

Track three dimensions:

  • Efficiency: cycle‑time reduction for equivalent tasks with‑AI.
  • Quality: defect rate/CSAT changes attributable to AI (studies show gains in satisfaction and retention).
  • Reuse: number of reusable prompts, workflows, and templates. Don’t worship KPI/OKR dashboards. HBR warns metrics divorced from strategy backfire; a common OKR mistake is treating tasks as outcomes.

4) Pragmatic hiring: prioritize “AI‑transferable ability,” not logos

Section titled “4) Pragmatic hiring: prioritize “AI‑transferable ability,” not logos”

Look for:

  • Translating business problems → data/tools → executable prompts;
  • Productizing personal workflows (scripts, macros, agents);
  • Ability to teach others (clear SOPs/templates);
  • Basic respect for security/compliance (data classification, red‑line awareness).

5) Structure: “small squads + toolchains,” learn by shipping

Section titled “5) Structure: “small squads + toolchains,” learn by shipping”

Avoid early over‑hiring. Use 4–6‑person squads (PM/eng/data/ops) bound to the same prompt library, KB, and automation scripts. Keep human–AI collaboration as assets — not screenshots of chats.

6) Process shift: from weekly/monthly reports to replayable workflows and real‑time metrics

Section titled “6) Process shift: from weekly/monthly reports to replayable workflows and real‑time metrics”

Reports aren’t the goal; reproducibility is.

  • Record canonical workflows as agent run + prompts + sample data;
  • Dashboard AI calls per capita, hours saved, reuse rate. As process reproducibility increases, outcomes follow; fixation on outcomes alone often reduces effectiveness. (Industry and research agree: deeper AI integration lifts both value and adoption.)

7) Cultural core: self‑discipline to enable others — turn anxiety into practice

Section titled “7) Cultural core: self‑discipline to enable others — turn anxiety into practice”

AI isn’t a replacement machine; it’s human augmentation. Stanford’s takeaway: replace humans with AI and you lose; augment humans with AI and you win. Manager moves:

  • Give “error budgets” and “learning budgets.”
  • Default to pair‑prompting so newcomers shorten ramp‑up (evidence shows bigger gains for juniors).

8) Don’t bet on shortcuts; bet on compounding

Section titled “8) Don’t bet on shortcuts; bet on compounding”

No magic curves, only compounding curves:

  • Ship one reusable workflow every week;
  • Monthly retro on “hours saved and quality held”;
  • Quarterly cleanup of tech‑ and data‑debt. AI adoption is like fitness — consistency compounds. Global data shows rapid enterprise adoption; failure to keep pace is falling behind.

Playbook: six 0→1 transformations

Section titled “Playbook: six 0→1 transformations”

A. People: three‑layer capability model

Section titled “A. People: three‑layer capability model”
  • Base: AI basics (retrieval, rewriting, structuring, review).
  • Middle: task‑chain orchestration (multi‑turn prompts, tool use, RAG/KB).
  • Top: business agentization (auto‑pull data, auto‑generate/execute, auto‑retro). Assessment: from “can use” to “can teach.” Promotions reward how many others you uplift.

B. Work: “list → template → automate” high‑frequency tasks

Section titled “B. Work: “list → template → automate” high‑frequency tasks”

Examples:

  • Pre‑sales: inquiry classification → auto‑reply drafts → CRM ingest → next‑touch reminders.
  • Engineering: requirements → cases → code → tests → deploy scaffolds.
  • Support: ticket similarity → answer drafts → second review → FAQ back to KB.

C. Tools: a three‑layer stack

Section titled “C. Tools: a three‑layer stack”
  • Collab: docs/KB/boards.
  • Intelligence: conversational orchestration (workflows/agents), function calling, RAG.
  • Monitoring: cost, quality, compliance, drift alerts. Requirement: everything output is reusable.

D. Data: governance first

Section titled “D. Data: governance first”

Label data by source, sensitivity, sharing scope, retention. Use de‑identified samples for training/chat; route outward content via human review + watermark.

E. Performance: define excellence as “leverage + learning speed”

Section titled “E. Performance: define excellence as “leverage + learning speed””

Keep OKRs, but write KRs as measurable AI leverage:

  • KR1: cycle time on key tasks (with‑AI) −30% or better.
  • KR2: ≥6 reusable workflows/month.
  • KR3: uplift teammate adoption and saved hours. Avoid KRs as task lists (“X meetings/Y reports”).

F. Budget: fund “output/cost,” not seat count

Section titled “F. Budget: fund “output/cost,” not seat count”

Spend on high‑reuse scenarios and data hygiene, not raw seats. Prove 3 payback flows before expansion.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI‑era management is simple: put an amplifier on everyone’s back, make every task machine‑reusable, and keep the org steady, clear, and fast. Skip anxiety, skip “shortcuts.” Stack small wins into compounding wins. Which three actions should your team AI‑enable first?

Tags:
  • AI
  • Team Management

A Tech Lead’s Day in the AI Era

Aug 19, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Don’t win by “how hard I grind,” win by “how much harder my team can grind.” With ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini in the loop, this schedule runs nearly twice as fast.

07:00 | Info Radar & Community Pulse (light warm‑up)

Section titled “07:00 | Info Radar & Community Pulse (light warm‑up)”

Actions

  • Scan AI updates on X; repost with a one‑line judgment.
  • Collect into a “materials inbox”: title, link, one‑line value.
  • Use a custom GPT in ChatGPT as a “morning brief secretary” to auto‑produce 3 team‑usable ideas (e.g., PRD leads, data points).

How to implement

  • Create a private GPT with a fixed output schema (source / summary / actionable advice). When needed, enable Advanced Data Analysis to OCR tables in screenshots into CSV.

One‑line prompt

“Sort these 5 AI news items by impact on our product. For each, give 1 actionable experiment. Output a table.”

08:00 | Commute launch ritual (prime momentum)

Section titled “08:00 | Commute launch ritual (prime momentum)”

Actions

  • Bring a book; don’t grind in transit — keep cadence steady.
  • Open ChatGPT Voice to dictate a brain‑dump; compress into 3 MITs with acceptance criteria. Voice is smoother than typing.

Voice prompt

“Help me compress today into 3 Most Important Tasks. For each: one sentence + acceptance criteria.”

09:00 | MIT deep‑work window (move the progress bar only)

Section titled “09:00 | MIT deep‑work window (move the progress bar only)”

Actions

  • Small changes: ship yourself; verify by results.
  • Big tasks: delegate, but state “goal + acceptance” crisply.
  • Use Gemini 1.5 long context: feed long docs/screens, ask for an acceptance checklist only.

One‑line prompt

“Read this PRD/user‑feedback screenshots. Output a checkbox acceptance list (binary ‘pass/fail’ only, no long sentences).”

10:00 | Coaching‑style meeting (less command, more questions)

Section titled “10:00 | Coaching‑style meeting (less command, more questions)”

Actions

  • Don’t grab the steering wheel; follow a “coach 50 minutes” rule — I don’t jump in, the team grows faster.
  • Do three things only: define boundaries, design the smallest validation, confirm the next milestone.
  • Use Claude Code as a “post‑meeting reviewer”: feed notes + code snippets + logs to produce a minimal next‑step experiment plan.

One‑line prompt

“From the meeting notes + this code, list two smallest experiments we can independently validate this week, including commands, expected outputs, and rollback conditions.”

12:00 | 1‑km walk (reset and long‑range thinking)

Section titled “12:00 | 1‑km walk (reset and long‑range thinking)”

Actions

  • Write while walking; it stabilizes the mind.
  • Creativity often spikes after walking/exercise; let the subconscious brew.

14:00 | Product QA (trim edges like pruning a tree)

Section titled “14:00 | Product QA (trim edges like pruning a tree)”

Actions

  • Use today’s build hands‑on; note 10 friction points while using it.
  • With ChatGPT Advanced Data Analysis, compare screenshots/analytics: before/after click paths, latency metrics, crash counts.
  • Send repeated issues to Gemini Code Assist or Claude Code for patch suggestions; use whichever integrates better with your IDE.

One‑line prompt

“Compare event CSVs from v1.6 vs v1.7. Show the average time from A to payment, as a table + a short diagnosis.”

15:00 | Support radar (turn emotions into a roadmap)

Section titled “15:00 | Support radar (turn emotions into a roadmap)”

Actions

  • Watch for tone and closure; push items to GitHub Projects: Issue → Owner → Due date → Linked PR.
  • Use GitHub Actions to automate: when PR is ready, auto‑create/label tasks.
  • Use Claude or ChatGPT to draft user replies — but you finalize the voice.

One‑line prompt

“Turn these 12 support notes into a release update using a four‑part structure: problem, fix, go‑live time, impact scope.”

16:00 | One hour of a hard book (judgment training)

Section titled “16:00 | One hour of a hard book (judgment training)”

Actions

  • Tech leads win on judgment, powered by cross‑discipline inputs.
  • Use ChatGPT Memory for long‑term preferences and study topics; auto‑link new chats to old notes. You can view/delete/disable memory anytime in settings.

One‑line prompt

“From my past chats on ‘AI experience metrics,’ pull the metrics I mentioned and compile a one‑page comparison (cite each item with the message date).”

18:00 | Leave on time (anti‑crunch team cadence)

Section titled “18:00 | Leave on time (anti‑crunch team cadence)”

Actions

  • Lead by example: keep efficiency in daylight, give evenings back to life.
  • Healthy rhythm sustains output.

19:00 | Dinner & 4‑km walk (roaming time)

Section titled “19:00 | Dinner & 4‑km walk (roaming time)”

Actions

  • While walking, use ChatGPT Voice or Gemini Live to dictate ideas → convert to todos.
  • Roaming aids creativity; walking’s boost is supported by research.

20:00 | Community issues / writing / study with kids (variable slot)

Section titled “20:00 | Community issues / writing / study with kids (variable slot)”

Actions

  • Merge patches; backfill tests.
  • If no heavy engineering, write a technical retro — invest in team knowledge.
  • Study time: use Claude or ChatGPT to explain solution thinking visually — don’t just give the answer.

One‑line prompt

“Explain this function problem in three diagrammed steps — Given → Transform → Substitute & Verify — with two‑sentence explanations + one common pitfall per step.”

22:00 | Support retro (attitude first)

Section titled “22:00 | Support retro (attitude first)”

Actions

  • Scan the day’s 3k+ support messages.
  • Skip good service; log poor cases → follow up next morning.
  • Use Gemini API for structured extraction: sentiment, module, severity; export a table for the next stand‑up.

23:00 | Heavy‑book sleep induction (power down)

Section titled “23:00 | Heavy‑book sleep induction (power down)”

Actions

  • Read 20 pages; wind down.
  • Sleep when sleepy.

Late night | Idea catcher (3 lines are enough)

Section titled “Late night | Idea catcher (3 lines are enough)”

Actions

  • Wake and jot three sentences, then sleep.
  • Next day, use ChatGPT/Gemini to expand them into a minimal experiment.

“Minimal Executable” AI checklist (copy‑ready)

Section titled ““Minimal Executable” AI checklist (copy‑ready)”
  • Morning brief secretary (ChatGPT GPTs): fixed output source / one‑line judgment / actionable experiment, keep historical comparisons.
  • Meeting retro → plan (Claude Code): notes + code + logs → two smallest experiments.
  • Long docs → acceptance list (Gemini 1.5): PRD/charts/screenshots → JSON acceptance points.
  • Support → Issue → PR (GitHub Actions): Ready‑for‑review → auto‑create cards and add to project.
  • Team knowledge backflow (ChatGPT Memory): persist “our experience metrics/style conventions” as long‑term memory; clear/disable when needed.
Tags:
  • AI
  • Team Management

Palantir Shorts vs. AI Hype: Valuation, Risks, and Opportunities

Aug 19, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Palantir Technologies (ticker: PLTR) has surged this year on the “artificial intelligence (AI)” narrative, becoming a market darling. Yet behind the stock’s multiple expansions, short sellers (e.g., Citron Research) argue its valuation has detached from fundamentals.

As investors, we should examine calmly: What are the core claims from the short side? How has AI euphoria inflated its multiples? What do the latest financials actually imply? What risks come with shorting this stock? Looking ahead, do Palantir’s government contracts and data platform commercialization provide mid‑ to long‑term upside?

The short case: sky‑high valuation and growth concerns

Section titled “The short case: sky‑high valuation and growth concerns”

1. Extreme multiples

  • Price‑to‑sales peaked around 80–100×; forward P/E 200–300×.
  • Citron’s Andrew Left called Palantir’s valuation “absurdly” rich.
  • Even on NVIDIA‑style multiples, Palantir could still need a major haircut.
  • Within the S&P 500, Palantir is cited as one of the most expensive names, with forward P/E ~245× vs NVIDIA ~35×.

2. Business model skepticism

  • OpenAI benefits from a self‑reinforcing user‑growth flywheel; Palantir relies largely on customized contracts.
  • Looks like “consulting + packaged software,” limiting scale efficiency.

3. Results and customer mix

  • Over half of revenue depends on U.S. government contracts.
  • Commercial expansion is slower (roughly 20% growth), falling short of AI‑boom expectations.

4. Insider selling

  • CEO Alex Karp has reportedly sold nearly $2B of stock over two years.
  • Interpreted as wavering confidence and fuels market doubts.

How AI euphoria skews valuation

Section titled “How AI euphoria skews valuation”
  • Global AI equities trade around 30× forward P/E, well above the S&P 500’s ~19×.
  • Palantir’s YTD gain exceeded 130% at one point, emblematic of the AI story trade.
  • Investors chase narrative over fundamentals; even Sam Altman has cautioned about bubble signs.

Double‑edged sword:

  • Upside: markets award premium multiples; some dub Palantir the “Oracle of AI.”
  • Risk: when heat fades, multiples can compress quickly.

Latest results and comp table

Section titled “Latest results and comp table”

Highlights:

  • 2025 Q2 revenue topped $1B for the first time, +48% YoY.
  • U.S. commercial +93% YoY; government +53%.
  • EPS $0.16; operating margin 46.3%; FCF margin 57%.

Valuation comps:

  • Palantir: P/S ~ 80×; P/E ~ 200–300×.
  • NVIDIA: P/E ~35×.
  • Microsoft/Google: P/E ~30×.
  • OpenAI (private): ~$500B valuation, P/S ~17×.

👉 On OpenAI‑style multiples, Palantir’s “fair” price might be around $40, well below spot.

Risks of shorting Palantir

Section titled “Risks of shorting Palantir”
  • Retail sponsorship: like GameStop, sentiment can squeeze price higher.
  • Low short interest: ~2.5% vs C3.ai’s ~20%.
  • Headline sensitivity: a big contract or AI milestone can spike shares and squeeze shorts.

Mid‑ to long‑term potential

Section titled “Mid‑ to long‑term potential”

1. Government moat

  • Long relationships with DoD and intelligence agencies; long cycles, large dollars.
  • Latest DoD contract reportedly expanded to $1.3B, running through 2029.

2. Commercial expansion

  • AIP (AI Platform) trials across banking, healthcare, and manufacturing.
  • Q2 added 157 $1M+ contracts — clear progress in commercialization.

3. Healthy financial profile

  • High gross margin and strong FCF; multiple profitable quarters.
  • Unlike “pure AI concept” names relying on external financing.

4. Structural tailwinds

  • Rising AI and analytics penetration.
  • Palantir could become the “enterprise data operating system.”
  • Some analysts have lifted targets to $150–200.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Palantir sits at a controversial crossroads:

  • Bears argue valuation far exceeds fundamentals and will normalize.
  • Bulls point to the government moat and AIP traction, expecting earnings to fill the gap.

Investor takeaway:

  • Beware of bubbles, but don’t ignore long‑term potential.
  • Near‑term volatility is high; both long and short carry risk.
  • Long‑run value will be determined by execution and landing real products.

In the short run, markets are a voting machine; in the long run, a weighing machine. Whether Palantir grows into its valuation will be answered by innovation and results.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • Palantir
  • NYSE: PLTR
  • AI
  • US Stock Market

Frontend AI Perk: Open-Source Open‑Lovable vs. Lovable — One‑Click Clone Any Website into a React App

Aug 14, 2025
Vibe Sparking

For engineers and creators who want to use AI to ship products faster and validate ideas more cost‑effectively.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Lovable has gone viral recently: you can chat to generate websites/apps, with pricing based on credits. It’s a fresh model and surprisingly fast. At the same time, the Mendable team released an open-source alternative open‑lovable: clone any website into a modern React app, run it locally, modify it, and extend it. For many teams, this route is more controllable and cost‑efficient.

What is open‑lovable?

Section titled “What is open‑lovable?”

In one sentence: Give it a URL, and in seconds it pulls page structure and assets and generates runnable Next.js/React code that you can develop locally. Under the hood it has two “engines”:

  • Firecrawl: crawls web content and converts it into LLM‑friendly structured data like Markdown/JSON/screenshots.
  • E2B Sandboxes: secure, isolated cloud sandboxes serving as an “AI code runtime,” letting agents run commands, read/write files, install packages, and access the network.

The official README clearly lists dependencies and steps (supports Anthropic, OpenAI, Gemini, or Groq — any/some combination). You’ll need E2B_API_KEY + FIRECRAWL_API_KEY, plus at least one model provider API key. Then npm run dev to try it at localhost:3000. License is MIT.

Key point: open‑lovable leans toward “clone + local control,” while Lovable is more of a “hosted AI app builder.”

What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?

Section titled “What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?”

Lovable is a chat‑based full‑stack app builder. It supports Agent/Chat/Code/visual editing, Figma import, and integrations like GitHub/Supabase/Stripe/Clerk — very friendly for non‑technical users and small teams; credit‑based billing, Pro starts at $25/month.

  • Agent Mode: it can “think, research, and change code” on its own — read code, debug, search docs, modify code, and test.
  • Visual Edits: click elements on the page to change copy/styles, and no credits are deducted.

The company’s growth is brisk — recent funding and revenue news suggest the category is validated.

Side‑by‑Side: open‑lovable vs. Lovable

Section titled “Side‑by‑Side: open‑lovable vs. Lovable”
Dimensionopen‑lovable (Open Source)Lovable (Commercial SaaS)
Core capabilityClone any website → generate Next.js/React code, develop locallyNatural‑language full‑stack generation, supports Agent/Chat/Visual Edits
Runtime formLocal/self‑hosted, MIT license, deeply modifiableHosted cloud, WYSIWYG
DependenciesFirecrawl crawling + E2B sandboxes + your chosen LLM providerBuilt‑in AI capabilities and many integrations
PricingOpen source free (you pay Firecrawl/E2B/model usage)Credit‑based, Pro from $25/month
AudienceDevs with frontend skills wanting fast clone + fast customizationTeams wanting zero‑barrier app/prototype with minimal code
Typical scenariosMigrate competitor/marketing pages; rebuild legacy stack into modern React0→1 prototypes, MVPs, internal tools, turning designs into code

(Sources: both products’ websites and docs/READMEs)

Hands‑On: 5‑Minute Local Setup for open‑lovable

Section titled “Hands‑On: 5‑Minute Local Setup for open‑lovable”
  1. Clone and install
  1. Configure environment variables (.env.local)
  1. Run

These steps and dependencies are clearly documented in the official README.

Tip: Firecrawl supports full‑site crawling/screenshots/Markdown/JSON; E2B sandboxes default to a 5‑minute lifetime, configurable.

Three Real Developer Scenarios

Section titled “Three Real Developer Scenarios”

Example 1: Competitor landing page → same‑day marketing site release

Section titled “Example 1: Competitor landing page → same‑day marketing site release”

Scenario: Marketing wants to A/B test a new copy/layout. Approach:

  • Use open‑lovable to clone a competitor page or your old landing page skeleton into React.
  • Locally wire copy, CTAs, and tracking scripts (GA/analytics).
  • Apply your design system/components, connect the backend form/CRM. Benefit: Finish “migrate + customize + ship” in hours, instead of re‑slicing assets and rewriting styles from scratch.

Tech note: Firecrawl extracts clean page content, reducing manual copy‑paste; Next.js structure is tidy, making CI/CD straightforward.

Example 2: Modernize an “it works but it’s old” site

Section titled “Example 2: Modernize an “it works but it’s old” site”

Scenario: The company site/docs run, but the stack is aging. Approach:

  • Clone the current site to generate modern React code.
  • Use E2B sandbox‑driven scripts for batch refactors (class naming, image optimization, extracting i18n, etc.).
  • Add Tailwind/your design system to unify visuals. Benefit: Re‑skin first without breaking functionality, improve maintainability, then iteratively extract components and data layers.

Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one

Section titled “Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one”

Scenario: Lots of new business ideas; leadership wants to “see something.” Approach:

  • Clone a public page from a similar product as the skeleton.
  • Use models to quickly swap in industry‑specific copy and inline interaction demos.
  • Integrate third‑party auth/payments/email (and migrate to a real backend later). Benefit: You have “something real” the same day. Reviews focus on product value rather than “we haven’t built the page yet.” (When you move toward production, switch to Cursor/local repo for continued evolution.)

If you want zero‑code 0→1, Lovable’s Agent/Visual Edits and integrations are smoother. The open‑source route fits teams that need engineering‑grade control of code.

Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain

Section titled “Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain”
  • GitHub Actions: on PRs, run Lighthouse/Playwright to watch performance and usability.
  • Supabase/Stripe/Clerk for MVP auth/payments/data. open‑lovable outputs standard React code, so integrate as usual; Lovable provides built‑in guides/templates for these services.
  • Model “mix‑and‑match”: use Claude/GPT‑5 for complex logic, Groq/Kimi K2 for speed; switch via env vars as needed.

How to Choose

Section titled “How to Choose”
  • You want to control code, cut subscriptions, and reuse existing web pages → open‑lovable.
  • You want 0→1 prototypes/internal tools fast, and value hosting and collaboration → Lovable.
  • Or use a combo: first use open‑lovable to grab the “shell” and refine locally; or validate product/flows in Lovable first, then “export/refactor” to self‑hosted.

Industry chatter often positions Lovable as “scaffolding + visual design/flow,” while serious projects return to local engineering for polishing. open‑lovable neatly covers the “engineering‑grade control” half.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI‑assisted development is bifurcating: one side is hosted, WYSIWYG (Lovable); the other is open‑source, controllable, engineering‑friendly (open‑lovable).
There’s no absolute right answer — your team’s cost/pace/governance needs matter most.

Which side do you lean toward? Where do you think open‑lovable fits best in your business? Share your real‑world scenarios in the comments.

Tags:
  • Open Lovable
  • Lovable
  • React
  • AI

terminalcp lets Claude Code manage Terminal sessions like Playwright

Aug 13, 2025
Vibe Sparking

In one sentence: terminalcp = Playwright for the terminal.
It lets an AI agent start, operate, and read any command‑line tool (LLDB/GDB, Python REPL, database shells, even other AI CLIs) like a human—and lets you and me take over the same session at any time.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

You may already use Playwright/Browser for web automation—so what about an “automation console” for the command line?
terminalcp abstracts “what a human does in the terminal” into an MCP tool: start a process → send keystrokes → read output → manage multiple sessions, and also supports socket attach so you can watch and take over the AI’s actions in real time.

Why add it to your toolchain?

Section titled “Why add it to your toolchain?”

1) Truly interactive control
Not just “run a command and exit,” but persistent sessions: single‑step in LLDB/GDB, try code in a REPL, or view the “full screen” in TUI apps like vim/htop.

2) Two output modes, pick as needed

  • Terminal mode (stdout): captures the rendered screen buffer, perfect for debuggers and TUIs.
  • Stream mode: captures the raw text stream (ANSI stripped by default), and supports incremental reads with since_last—more efficient for builds/logs.

3) High‑fidelity PTY
Processes run in a pseudo‑terminal, preserving colors/cursor moves/special key sequences—just like human input; plus it manages multiple processes in the background so your agent doesn’t block.

4) Socket attach: the key to human–AI collaboration
Each process automatically exposes a Unix domain socket. You can attach to an already‑running AI session to co‑view and co‑operate, jumping in to help anytime.

5) More “AI‑friendly” than screen/tmux

  • Structured responses (JSON) instead of a wall of text.
  • Clean output (ANSI can be stripped), easier to feed into an LLM.
  • Incremental reads and lifecycle management (exit codes, etc.) built in.

Install and quick start (works with any MCP client)

Section titled “Install and quick start (works with any MCP client)”

Standard config (works for most tools)
Add the server in your MCP client:

Claude Code (CLI)

Cursor
Settings → MCP → Add new MCP Server
Name: terminalcp, Type: command, Command:
npx @mariozechner/terminalcp@latest.

VS Code (incl. Copilot Agent)

After installation, GitHub Copilot Agent in VS Code can use it directly.

Windsurf / other MCP clients
Follow their MCP docs with the “standard config” above, or install globally first:

Then configure:

Requirements: Node.js ≥ 18; any MCP‑capable client (VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Desktop, Goose, etc.).

How does it work with Claude Code / Cursor?

Section titled “How does it work with Claude Code / Cursor?”

Principle: terminalcp exposes a single MCP tool terminal, and you control sessions via JSON commands: start / stdin / stdout / stream / stop / list / term-size.

Workflow A: Let Claude control another AI CLI

Section titled “Workflow A: Let Claude control another AI CLI”
  1. Start Claude/Gemini CLIs (use an absolute path; shell aliases won’t work):
  1. Send input (auto submit/Enter):
  1. Read the full screen (great for TUI/debugger UIs):
  1. Clean up the process:

Shell aliases don’t apply; for interactive CLIs prefer submit:true; remember to stop when done.

Workflow B: Tail builds/logs incrementally

Section titled “Workflow B: Tail builds/logs incrementally”

ANSI is stripped by default; set strip_ansi:false if you need color codes.

Workflow C: REPL / debugging

Section titled “Workflow C: REPL / debugging”

Python REPL

LLDB

Collaboration superpower: socket attach (tmux‑like, but smarter)

Section titled “Collaboration superpower: socket attach (tmux‑like, but smarter)”

Name the process when starting it:

From your local terminal, list and attach:

  • Operate together in your own terminal;
  • Ctrl+Q to detach without killing the session;
  • Supports multiple concurrent attachments;
  • Socket paths live under ~/.terminalcp/sessions/.

How it differs from screen/tmux (tested: better for AI)

Section titled “How it differs from screen/tmux (tested: better for AI)”
  • Structured responses: JSON replies that are easy for agents to parse.
  • Reliable output capture: stdout gives the rendered screen; stream supports incremental “since_last” reads.
  • Less noise: ANSI control codes stripped by default so escape sequences don’t swamp your context.
  • State‑aware: detects process exit and error codes.
  • No guessing timing: avoids brittle sleep‑style “maybe it’s done” waits.
    You can “simulate” some of this with tmux/screen, but it’s tedious and fragile.

Best‑practice checklist

Section titled “Best‑practice checklist”
  • Use absolute paths for CLIs (e.g., Claude CLI); shell aliases don’t apply.
  • For interactive commands, use {"submit":true}—or send text and \r as two steps.
  • Use stream + since_last for long tasks to avoid re‑pulling full logs.
  • Name sessions + attach via sockets for quick collaboration and fire‑fighting.
  • Explicitly stop when finished; on MCP client exit, leftover processes are auto‑cleaned.
  • Licensed MIT—safe to integrate into internal toolchains.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

If you’re building AI‑assisted development / internal DevTools / AIOps, terminalcp turns “everything in the terminal” into an orchestrable API: agent control, human–agent co‑operation, automation with visibility. Starting today, let your AI not just “run commands,” but actually “use the terminal.”

Where will you plug it in first?
Build logs, kernel debugging, on‑call incident response—or turning Claude/Gemini into controllable “sub‑agents”? What do you think?

📦 Appendix: copy‑and‑paste quick reference

Section titled “📦 Appendix: copy‑and‑paste quick reference”

MCP standard config (works for most clients)

Claude Code CLI

VS Code CLI

Global install (optional)

Tags:
  • terminalcp
  • AI
  • MCP
  • Terminal
  • Tmux
  • Screen

Gemini Storybook Adds Chinese Narration; Print/Export to PDF for Instant Picture Books

Aug 9, 2025
Vibe Sparking

One-sentence version: Gemini’s Storybook just shipped new features — native Chinese read‑aloud, multiple illustration styles, and print/export to PDF from the web. Make a personalized picture book for your child in under one minute.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Have you had this moment? It’s bedtime and your child suddenly wants “Super Dino goes to Mars”; your drawers are stuffed with kids’ drawings you can’t bear to toss. Storybook turns those sparks into a 10‑page illustrated tale with voice narration in one click, and can “weave” your child’s photos or doodles right into the scenes.

Three upgrades that matter

Section titled “Three upgrades that matter”

1) Native Chinese narration, ready to go

Section titled “1) Native Chinese narration, ready to go”

Google has rolled out Read‑aloud, noting supported languages will expand over time; both media reports and hands‑on tests indicate Chinese is already available, so parents can listen to the story in Chinese directly. The delivery sounds natural and smooth — perfect for bedtime.

Key point: 45+ languages covered (text and audio), available on both mobile and web.

2) “Unlimited styles” at your fingertips

Section titled “2) “Unlimited styles” at your fingertips”

Watercolor, anime, pixel art, claymation, coloring book? Switch styles with a single line, and even upload your child’s photo or doodles as inspiration for the illustrations. You can also tweak character names and scene details anytime, then generate a new version.

Official examples: from explaining the “solar system” to “moving house,” education scenarios work great too.

3) One click to booklet — easy to share/print

Section titled “3) One click to booklet — easy to share/print”

Every story generates a shareable link; on the web you can print directly. In practice, Print to PDF gives you a file you can take straight to the print shop.

How to use it in three steps

Section titled “How to use it in three steps”
  1. Open Gemini and start a chat: “Help me make a storybook titled ‘The Shy Dinosaur Learns to Dance’, watercolor style, for a 5‑year‑old.”
  2. Add ingredients: upload your child’s dinosaur drawing/photo; specify the hero’s name and what the little monster likes to eat.
  3. Tweak: ask for “funnier” or “switch to anime style,” generate a new version; tap Read‑aloud to play.

Real‑world use cases you can try now

Section titled “Real‑world use cases you can try now”
  • 10 minutes before bed: turn “a small kindergarten scuffle” into a reconciliation adventure.
  • Mini lessons: explain the “solar system/trash sorting/traffic safety” in a coloring‑book style.
  • Memory book: stitch travel photos and family snapshots into “Our Jeju Island Adventure.”

Tips (pitfall avoidance)

Section titled “Tips (pitfall avoidance)”
  • Narration languages: the note says “Read‑aloud is currently available in select languages”. If you don’t see the button, switch languages or wait for updates.
  • Character consistency: AI illustrations can occasionally drift (e.g., character details change). Use photos and reinforce key attributes to improve consistency.
  • Sharing permissions: Work/school accounts may not allow public sharing; a personal account is most reliable.

Why this update is worth it

Section titled “Why this update is worth it”
  • Barrier lowered to “say it and create”: parents, teachers, and creators can quickly bring ideas to life.
  • More reliable companionship: lean on AI narration when busy; read in person when free — switch as needed.
  • Style freedom at scale: from pixel art to claymation to your child’s own drawings — highly personalized.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Storybook lowers the bar for “telling a good story” to simply “saying a sentence.” Chinese narration works, styles are playful, and print‑ready PDFs are easy to take with you. You bring the ideas — it binds them into a book of love. Which one will you make first? Tell me your first theme in the comments.

Tags:
  • AI
  • Google Gemini
  • Story Book

Parents' Superpower: Gemini Story Book for Creative Family Storytelling

Aug 7, 2025
Vibe Sparking

One-Minute Overview Google Gemini’s newly launched Story Book feature transforms a single spark of inspiration into a complete 10-page illustrated e-book with audio narration. Supporting 45+ languages and custom art styles, it can even incorporate children’s doodles as source material—saving time for parents, sparking creativity in kids, and enabling rapid prototyping for professional authors.

✨ What Makes Gemini Story Book Magical?

Section titled “✨ What Makes Gemini Story Book Magical?”
  • 10-Page Books: One prompt generates complete text + illustrations + narration package.
  • Any Art Style: Pixel art, clay animation, comics, or even black-and-white coloring books—plus photo uploads for custom characters.
  • 45 Languages: Multi-language narration makes bedtime stories work across cultures.
  • One-Minute Creation: Cloud rendering means even smartphones can handle it.

👪 For Parents: No More “Running Out of Stories”

Section titled “👪 For Parents: No More “Running Out of Stories””

Scenario: Creating “Brave Little Dinosaur’s Sleep Quest” in 5 Minutes

10-Page Script

Section titled “10-Page Script”
  1. In the twilight forest, little dinosaur Harbi rubs his eyes but can’t fall asleep.
  2. He meets glowing fireflies and asks them to sing a lullaby.
  3. The fireflies say: “First learn to breathe deeply.”
  4. Harbi goes “Whooo—breathe—” and his heartbeat slows down.
  5. Grandma Moon sends down a warm moonbeam blanket.
  6. Baby stars dance, arranging themselves into “Zzz” in the night sky.
  7. Grandpa Wind sways the treetops, playing a rustling lullaby.
  8. Harbi feels his eyelids grow heavy and lets out a big yawn.
  9. He snuggles into the moonbeam blanket and says goodnight to the fireflies.
  10. Final scene: Harbi sleeps with a smile as the starry sky grows peaceful.

➡️ How-to: Paste these 10 segments into Story Book, select “hand-drawn watercolor” style, and within 30 seconds you have an illustrated book with narration. Kids enjoy the pictures while parents get their hands free.

👧 For Kids: Become the Director

Section titled “👧 For Kids: Become the Director”

Scenario: Yuyu and the Little Robot Learn Programming

10-Page Script

Section titled “10-Page Script”
  1. In the classroom, 7-year-old Yuyu receives a mini robot.
  2. The robot says: “Give me commands, let’s go on an adventure!”
  3. Yuyu writes move forward on her tablet.
  4. The robot crosses the rainbow building block bridge.
  5. turn left—it walks around the sleeping cat.
  6. pick flower—its arm extends to pluck a blue flower.
  7. The petals turn into a rain of numbers, screen displays “Hello World!”
  8. Yuyu exclaims with delight: code can make the world come alive!
  9. She writes a new command: dance().
  10. The robot dances with Yuyu, shouting “Coding is fun!”

➡️ How-to: Kids paste their script into Story Book, choose “pixel comic” style, and generate their own “Programming Adventure” book that’s both educational and entertaining.

🖋️ For Story Creators: Concept to Prototype in One Minute

Section titled “🖋️ For Story Creators: Concept to Prototype in One Minute”

Scenario: “Coffee Cat’s Time Travel” Proposal

10-Page Script

Section titled “10-Page Script”
  1. An orange cat in a coffee shop steps on an alarm clock and travels back to 1925.
  2. A vintage streetcar clangs by as it searches everywhere for coffee beans.
  3. It meets a lady in a blue apron who hands over a steam coffee machine.
  4. The steam becomes a time tunnel, and the cat tumbles into 2050.
  5. A robot barista serves it cold brew.
  6. The adorable cat presses the “Home” button, and time reverses.
  7. Back at the original shop, it discovers the coffee smells even better.
  8. Customers line up to try the “Temporal Special Blend.”
  9. The orange cat lies on the counter, tail gently swaying.
  10. Finale: The shop sign gains a new line—“Thanks to our time traveler.”

➡️ How-to: Author pastes script → selects “steampunk oil painting” style → generates prototype booklet, then decides whether to develop the script and artwork further. From inspiration to finished product in just 60 seconds.

🏁 Conclusion

Section titled “🏁 Conclusion”

Story Book = One-Click Picture Book Factory.

  • Parents save time, making companionship more relaxed
  • Kids become protagonists, creativity soars
  • Authors iterate quickly, accelerating market validation

Give it a try—toss your script into Gemini and see what delightful surprises it serves up!

(Which scenario do you find most practical? Share your thoughts in the comments! 🎈)
